<h1 class="firstHeading" id="firstHeading" lang="en">Barack Obama</h1>
<div class="mw-body-content" id="bodyContent">
<div class="noprint" id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
<div id="contentSub"></div>
<div id="jump-to-nav"></div>
<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#mw-head">Jump to navigation</a>
<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#p-search">Jump to search</a>
<div class="mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr" id="mw-content-text" lang="en"><div class="mw-parser-output"><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">For other uses, see <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Barack_Obama_(disambiguation)" title="Barack Obama (disambiguation)">Barack Obama (disambiguation)</a>.</div>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">"Barack" and "Obama" redirect here. For other uses, see <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Barack_(disambiguation)" title="Barack (disambiguation)">Barack (disambiguation)</a> and <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Obama_(disambiguation)" title="Obama (disambiguation)">Obama (disambiguation)</a>.</div>
<p class="mw-empty-elt">
</p>
<div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none"> 44th president of the United States</div>
<p class="mw-empty-elt">

</tr><tr><td class="plainlist" style="padding:0.3em 0.4em 0.3em;font-weight:bold;border-top: 1px solid #aaa; border-bottom: 1px solid #aaa;line-height:1.6em;">
<ul><li><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:A_coloured_voting_box.svg"><img alt="A coloured voting box.svg" class="noviewer" data-file-height="160" data-file-width="160" decoding="async" height="16" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/01/A_coloured_voting_box.svg/16px-A_coloured_voting_box.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/01/A_coloured_voting_box.svg/24px-A_coloured_voting_box.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/01/A_coloured_voting_box.svg/32px-A_coloured_voting_box.svg.png 2x" width="16"/></a> <a href="/wiki/Portal:Politics" title="Portal:Politics">Politics portal</a></li></ul></td></tr><tr><td style="text-align:right;font-size:115%;padding-top: 0.6em;"><div class="plainlinks hlist navbar mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:New_Democrats" title="Template:New Democrats"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:New_Democrats" title="Template talk:New Democrats"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:New_Democrats&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Barack Hussein Obama II</b> (<span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="'b' in 'buy'">b</span><span title="/…ô/: 'a' in 'about'">…ô</span><span title="/Àà/: primary stress follows">Àà</span><span title="'r' in 'rye'">r</span><span title="/…ëÀê/: 'a' in 'father'">…ëÀê</span><span title="'k' in 'kind'">k</span></span><span class="wrap"> </span><span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="'h' in 'hi'">h</span><span title="/uÀê/: 'oo' in 'goose'">uÀê</span><span title="/Àà/: primary stress follows">Àà</span><span title="'s' in 'sigh'">s</span><span title="/e…™/: 'a' in 'face'">e…™</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span></span><span class="wrap"> </span><span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/o ä/: 'o' in 'code'">o ä</span><span title="/Àà/: primary stress follows">Àà</span><span title="'b' in 'buy'">b</span><span title="/…ëÀê/: 'a' in 'father'">…ëÀê</span><span title="'m' in 'my'">m</span><span title="/…ô/: 'a' in 'about'">…ô</span></span>/</a></span> <span class="nowrap" style="font-size:85%">(<span class="unicode haudio"><span class="fn"><span style="white-space:nowrap;margin-right:.25em;"><a href="/wiki/File:En-us-Barack-Hussein-Obama.ogg" title="About this sound"><img alt="About this sound" data-file-height="20" data-file-width="20" decoding="async" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" width="11"/></a></span><a class="internal" href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/8/82/En-us-Barack-Hussein-Obama.ogg" title="En-us-Barack-Hussein-Obama.ogg">listen</a></span></span>)</span></span>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-1"><a href="#cite_note-1">[1]</a></sup> born August 4, 1961) is an American attorney and politician who served as the 44th <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_United_States" title="President of the United States">President of the United States</a> from 2009 to 2017. A member of the <a href="/wiki/Democratic_Party_(United_States)" title="Democratic Party (United States)">Democratic Party</a>, he was the first <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/African_American" title="African American">African American</a> President of the United States. He previously served as a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/U.S._senator" title="U.S. senator">U.S. senator</a> from <a href="/wiki/Illinois" title="Illinois">Illinois</a> from 2005 to 2008 and an <a href="/wiki/Illinois_Senate" title="Illinois Senate">Illinois state senator</a> from 1997 to 2004.
</p><p>Obama was born in <a href="/wiki/Honolulu" title="Honolulu">Honolulu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hawaii" title="Hawaii">Hawaii</a>. After graduating from <a href="/wiki/Columbia_University" title="Columbia University">Columbia University</a> in 1983, he worked as a community organizer in <a href="/wiki/Chicago" title="Chicago">Chicago</a>. In 1988, he enrolled in <a href="/wiki/Harvard_Law_School" title="Harvard Law School">Harvard Law School</a>, where he was the first black president of the <i><a href="/wiki/Harvard_Law_Review" title="Harvard Law Review">Harvard Law Review</a></i>. After graduating, he became a civil rights attorney and an academic, teaching constitutional law at the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Chicago_Law_School" title="University of Chicago Law School">University of Chicago Law School</a> from 1992 to 2004. He <a href="/wiki/Illinois_Senate_career_of_Barack_Obama" title="Illinois Senate career of Barack Obama">represented the 13th district for three terms</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Illinois_Senate" title="Illinois Senate">Illinois Senate</a> from 1997 until 2004, when he <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_States_Senate_election_in_Illinois,_2004" title="United States Senate election in Illinois, 2004">ran for the U.S. Senate</a>. He received national attention in 2004 with his March primary win, his well-received July <a href="/wiki/2004_Democratic_National_Convention" title="2004 Democratic National Convention">Democratic National Convention</a> <a href="/wiki/2004_Democratic_National_Convention_keynote_address" title="2004 Democratic National Convention keynote address">keynote address</a>, and his landslide November election to the Senate. In 2008, he was nominated for president a year after <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Barack_Obama_presidential_campaign,_2008" title="Barack Obama presidential campaign, 2008">his campaign</a> began, after <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Democratic_Party_presidential_primaries,_2008" title="Democratic Party presidential primaries, 2008">a close primary campaign</a> against <a href="/wiki/Hillary_Clinton" title="Hillary Clinton">Hillary Clinton</a>. He was <a href="/wiki/2008_United_States_presidential_election" title="2008 United States presidential election">elected</a> over <a href="/wiki/Republican_Party_(United_States)" title="Republican Party (United States)">Republican</a> <a href="/wiki/John_McCain" title="John McCain">John McCain</a> and was <a href="/wiki/First_inauguration_of_Barack_Obama" title="First inauguration of Barack Obama">inaugurated</a> on January 20, 2009. Nine months later, he was named the <a href="/wiki/2009_Nobel_Peace_Prize" title="2009 Nobel Peace Prize">2009 Nobel Peace Prize</a> laureate.
</p><p>Regarded as a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Centrist" title="Centrist">centrist</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/New_Democrat" title="New Democrat">New Democrat</a>, Obama signed many landmark bills into law during his first two years in office. The main reforms that were passed include the <a href="/wiki/Patient_Protection_and_Affordable_Care_Act" title="Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act">Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act</a> (commonly referred to as the "Affordable Care Act" or "Obamacare"), the <a href="/wiki/Dodd%E2%80%93Frank_Wall_Street_Reform_and_Consumer_Protection_Act" title="Dodd‚ÄìFrank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act">Dodd‚ÄìFrank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Don%27t_Ask,_Don%27t_Tell_Repeal_Act_of_2010" title="Don't Ask, Don't Tell Repeal Act of 2010">Don't Ask, Don't Tell Repeal Act of 2010</a>. The <a href="/wiki/American_Recovery_and_Reinvestment_Act_of_2009" title="American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009">American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tax_Relief,_Unemployment_Insurance_Reauthorization,_and_Job_Creation_Act_of_2010" title="Tax Relief, Unemployment Insurance Reauthorization, and Job Creation Act of 2010">Tax Relief, Unemployment Insurance Reauthorization, and Job Creation Act of 2010</a> served as economic stimulus amidst the <a href="/wiki/Great_Recession" title="Great Recession">Great Recession</a>. After a lengthy debate over the national debt limit, he signed the <a href="/wiki/Budget_Control_Act_of_2011" title="Budget Control Act of 2011">Budget Control</a> and the <a href="/wiki/American_Taxpayer_Relief_Act_of_2012" title="American Taxpayer Relief Act of 2012">American Taxpayer Relief Acts</a>. In foreign policy, he increased U.S. troop levels in <a href="/wiki/War_in_Afghanistan_(2001%E2%80%93present)" title="War in Afghanistan (2001‚Äìpresent)">Afghanistan</a>, reduced nuclear weapons with the United States‚ÄìRussia <a href="/wiki/New_START" title="New START">New START</a> treaty, and <a href="/wiki/Withdrawal_of_U.S._troops_from_Iraq" title="Withdrawal of U.S. troops from Iraq">ended military involvement</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Iraq_War" title="Iraq War">Iraq War</a>. He ordered <a href="/wiki/2011_military_intervention_in_Libya" title="2011 military intervention in Libya">military involvement in Libya</a>, contributing to the overthrow of <a href="/wiki/Muammar_Gaddafi" title="Muammar Gaddafi">Muammar Gaddafi</a>. He also ordered the military operations that resulted in <a href="/wiki/Death_of_Osama_bin_Laden" title="Death of Osama bin Laden">the deaths of Osama bin Laden</a> and suspected Yemeni <a href="/wiki/Al-Qaeda" title="Al-Qaeda">Al-Qaeda</a> operative <a href="/wiki/Anwar_al-Awlaki" title="Anwar al-Awlaki">Anwar al-Awlaki</a>.
</p><p>After winning <a href="/wiki/2012_United_States_presidential_election" title="2012 United States presidential election">re-election</a> by defeating Republican opponent <a href="/wiki/Mitt_Romney" title="Mitt Romney">Mitt Romney</a>, Obama was <a href="/wiki/Second_inauguration_of_Barack_Obama" title="Second inauguration of Barack Obama">sworn in for a second term</a> in 2013. During this term, he promoted inclusiveness for <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/LGBT_American" title="LGBT American">LGBT Americans</a>. His administration filed briefs that urged the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States" title="Supreme Court of the United States">Supreme Court</a> to strike down <a href="/wiki/Same-sex_marriage_in_the_United_States" title="Same-sex marriage in the United States">same-sex marriage</a> bans as unconstitutional (<i><a href="/wiki/United_States_v._Windsor" title="United States v. Windsor">United States v. Windsor</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Obergefell_v._Hodges" title="Obergefell v. Hodges">Obergefell v. Hodges</a></i>); same-sex marriage was fully <a href="/wiki/Same-sex_marriage_in_the_United_States" title="Same-sex marriage in the United States">legalized</a> in 2015 after the Court ruled that a same-sex marriage ban was unconstitutional in <i><a href="/wiki/Obergefell_v._Hodges" title="Obergefell v. Hodges">Obergefell</a></i>. He advocated for <a href="/wiki/Gun_politics_in_the_United_States" title="Gun politics in the United States">gun control</a> in response to the <a href="/wiki/Sandy_Hook_Elementary_School_shooting" title="Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting">Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting</a>, indicating support for a ban on <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Assault_weapons" title="Assault weapons">assault weapons</a>, and issued wide-ranging executive actions concerning <a href="/wiki/Global_warming" title="Global warming">global warming</a> and immigration. In foreign policy, he ordered <a href="/wiki/American-led_intervention_in_Iraq_(2014%E2%80%93present)" title="American-led intervention in Iraq (2014‚Äìpresent)">military intervention in Iraq</a> in response to gains made by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISIL" title="ISIL">ISIL</a> after the 2011 withdrawal from Iraq, continued the process of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ending_U.S._combat_operations_in_Afghanistan" title="Ending U.S. combat operations in Afghanistan">ending U.S. combat operations in Afghanistan</a> in 2016, promoted discussions that led to the 2015 <a href="/wiki/Paris_Agreement" title="Paris Agreement">Paris Agreement</a> on global climate change, initiated <a href="/wiki/International_sanctions_during_the_Ukrainian_crisis" title="International sanctions during the Ukrainian crisis">sanctions against Russia</a> following the <a href="/wiki/Russian_military_intervention_in_Ukraine_(2014%E2%80%93present)" title="Russian military intervention in Ukraine (2014‚Äìpresent)">invasion in Ukraine</a> and again after <a href="/wiki/Russian_interference_in_the_2016_United_States_elections" title="Russian interference in the 2016 United States elections">Russian interference in the 2016 United States elections</a>, brokered a <a href="/wiki/Joint_Comprehensive_Plan_of_Action" title="Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action">nuclear deal with Iran</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_States%E2%80%93Cuban_Thaw" title="United States‚ÄìCuban Thaw">normalized U.S. relations with Cuba</a>. Obama nominated <a href="/wiki/Barack_Obama_Supreme_Court_candidates" title="Barack Obama Supreme Court candidates">three justices to the Supreme Court</a>: <a href="/wiki/Sonia_Sotomayor" title="Sonia Sotomayor">Sonia Sotomayor</a> and <a href="/wiki/Elena_Kagan" title="Elena Kagan">Elena Kagan</a> were confirmed as justices, while <a href="/wiki/Merrick_Garland" title="Merrick Garland">Merrick Garland</a> faced unprecedented partisan <a href="/wiki/Merrick_Garland_Supreme_Court_nomination" title="Merrick Garland Supreme Court nomination">obstruction</a> and was ultimately not confirmed. During his term in office, America's <a href="/wiki/Soft_power" title="Soft power">soft power</a> and reputation abroad significantly improved.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2"><a href="#cite_note-2">[2]</a></sup>
</p><p>Obama's presidency has generally been regarded favorably, and evaluations of his presidency among historians, political scientists, and the general public place him among <a href="/wiki/Historical_rankings_of_presidents_of_the_United_States#Notable_scholar_surveys" title="Historical rankings of presidents of the United States">the upper tier</a> of American presidents. Obama left office and retired in January 2017 and currently resides in <a href="/wiki/Washington,_D.C." title="Washington, D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-3"><a href="#cite_note-3">[3]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-How_Does_Trump_Stack_Up_Against_the_Best‚Äîand_Worst‚ÄîPresidents?_4-0"><a href="#cite_note-How_Does_Trump_Stack_Up_Against_the_Best‚Äîand_Worst‚ÄîPresidents?-4">[4]</a></sup> A December 2018 <a href="/wiki/Gallup%27s_most_admired_man_and_woman_poll" title="Gallup's most admired man and woman poll">Gallup poll</a> found Obama to be the most admired man in America for an unprecedented 11th consecutive year, although <a href="/wiki/Dwight_D._Eisenhower" title="Dwight D. Eisenhower">Dwight D. Eisenhower</a> was selected most admired in twelve non-consecutive years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-5"><a href="#cite_note-5">[5]</a></sup>
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r886046785">.mw-parser-output .toclimit-2 .toclevel-1 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-3 .toclevel-2 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-4 .toclevel-3 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-5 .toclevel-4 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-6 .toclevel-5 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-7 .toclevel-6 ul{display:none}</style><div class="toclimit-4"><div class="toc" id="toc"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2>Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_life_and_career">Early life and career</span></h2>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Early_life_and_career_of_Barack_Obama" title="Early life and career of Barack Obama">Early life and career of Barack Obama</a></div>
<p>Obama was born on August 4, 1961,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-biography_6-0"><a href="#cite_note-biography-6">[6]</a></sup> at <a href="/wiki/Kapiolani_Medical_Center_for_Women_and_Children" title="Kapiolani Medical Center for Women and Children">Kapiolani Medical Center for Women and Children</a> in <a href="/wiki/Honolulu" title="Honolulu">Honolulu</a>, Hawaii.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-birth-certificate_7-0"><a href="#cite_note-birth-certificate-7">[7]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-maraniss_8-0"><a href="#cite_note-maraniss-8">[8]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-9"><a href="#cite_note-9">[9]</a></sup> He is the only president born outside the <a href="/wiki/Contiguous_United_States" title="Contiguous United States">contiguous</a> 48 states.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BarretoO'Bryant2013_10-0"><a href="#cite_note-BarretoO'Bryant2013-10">[10]</a></sup> He was born to a white mother and a black father. His mother, <a href="/wiki/Ann_Dunham" title="Ann Dunham">Ann Dunham</a> (1942‚Äì1995), was born in <a href="/wiki/Wichita,_Kansas" title="Wichita, Kansas">Wichita, Kansas</a>; she was mostly of English descent,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-11"><a href="#cite_note-11">[11]</a></sup> with some German, Irish, Scottish, Swiss, and Welsh ancestry.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-12"><a href="#cite_note-12">[12]</a></sup> His father, <a href="/wiki/Barack_Obama_Sr." title="Barack Obama Sr.">Barack Obama Sr.</a> (1936‚Äì1982), was a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Luo_people_of_Kenya_and_Tanzania" title="Luo people of Kenya and Tanzania">Luo Kenyan</a> from <a href="/wiki/Nyang%27oma_Kogelo" title="Nyang'oma Kogelo">Nyang'oma Kogelo</a>. Obama's parents met in 1960 in a <a href="/wiki/Russian_language" title="Russian language">Russian language</a> class at the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Hawaii_at_Manoa" title="University of Hawaii at Manoa">University of Hawaii at Manoa</a>, where his father was a foreign student on a scholarship.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jones_2007_13-0"><a href="#cite_note-Jones_2007-13">[13]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Obama_1995,_2004,_pp._9‚Äì10_14-0"><a href="#cite_note-Obama_1995,_2004,_pp._9‚Äì10-14">[14]</a></sup> The couple married in <a href="/wiki/Wailuku,_Hawaii" title="Wailuku, Hawaii">Wailuku, Hawaii</a>, on February 2, 1961, six months before Obama was born.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ripley_2008_15-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ripley_2008-15">[15]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-16"><a href="#cite_note-16">[16]</a></sup>
</p><p>In late August 1961, a few weeks after he was born, Barack and his mother moved to the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Washington" title="University of Washington">University of Washington</a> in <a href="/wiki/Seattle" title="Seattle">Seattle</a>, where they lived for a year. During that time, the elder Obama completed his undergraduate degree in <a href="/wiki/Economics" title="Economics">economics</a> in Hawaii, graduating in June 1962. He left to attend graduate school on a scholarship at <a href="/wiki/Harvard_University" title="Harvard University">Harvard University</a>, where he earned an <a href="/wiki/Master_of_Arts" title="Master of Arts">M.A.</a> in economics. Obama's parents divorced in March 1964.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-17"><a href="#cite_note-17">[17]</a></sup> Obama Sr. returned to Kenya in 1964, where he married for a third time and worked for the Kenyan government as the Senior Economic Analyst in the Ministry of Finance.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-18"><a href="#cite_note-18">[18]</a></sup> He visited his son in Hawaii only once, at Christmas 1971,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-19"><a href="#cite_note-19">[19]</a></sup> before he was killed in an automobile accident in 1982, when Obama was 21 years old.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-20"><a href="#cite_note-20">[20]</a></sup> Recalling his early childhood, Obama said, "That my father looked nothing like the people around me‚Äîthat he was black as pitch, my mother white as milk‚Äîbarely registered in my mind."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Obama_1995,_2004,_pp._9‚Äì10_14-1"><a href="#cite_note-Obama_1995,_2004,_pp._9‚Äì10-14">[14]</a></sup> He described his struggles as a young adult to reconcile social perceptions of his multiracial heritage.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-21"><a href="#cite_note-21">[21]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:152px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Barack_Obama_Sr_Jr.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="327" data-file-width="262" decoding="async" height="187" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/e/e8/Barack_Obama_Sr_Jr.jpg/150px-Barack_Obama_Sr_Jr.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/e/e8/Barack_Obama_Sr_Jr.jpg/225px-Barack_Obama_Sr_Jr.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/e/e8/Barack_Obama_Sr_Jr.jpg 2x" width="150"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Barack_Obama_Sr_Jr.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Obama (right) with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Barack_Obama,_Sr." title="Barack Obama, Sr.">his father</a> in <a href="/wiki/Hawaii" title="Hawaii">Hawaii</a>, 1971</div></div></div>
<p>In 1963, Dunham met <a href="/wiki/Lolo_Soetoro" title="Lolo Soetoro">Lolo Soetoro</a> at the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Hawaii" title="University of Hawaii">University of Hawaii</a>; he was an <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Native_Indonesian" title="Native Indonesian">Indonesian</a> <a href="/wiki/East%E2%80%93West_Center" title="East‚ÄìWest Center">East‚ÄìWest Center</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Graduate_student" title="Graduate student">graduate student</a> in <a href="/wiki/Geography" title="Geography">geography</a>. The couple married on <a href="/wiki/Molokai" title="Molokai">Molokai</a> on March 15, 1965.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-22"><a href="#cite_note-22">[22]</a></sup> After two one-year extensions of his <a href="/wiki/J-1_visa" title="J-1 visa">J-1 visa</a>, Lolo returned to <a href="/wiki/Indonesia" title="Indonesia">Indonesia</a> in 1966. His wife and stepson followed sixteen months later in 1967. The family initially lived in the Menteng Dalam neighborhood in the <a href="/wiki/Tebet,_South_Jakarta" title="Tebet, South Jakarta">Tebet</a> sub district of <a href="/wiki/South_Jakarta" title="South Jakarta">south Jakarta</a>. From 1970, they lived in a wealthier neighborhood in the <a href="/wiki/Menteng" title="Menteng">Menteng</a> sub district of <a href="/wiki/Central_Jakarta" title="Central Jakarta">central Jakarta</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-23"><a href="#cite_note-23">[23]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h3>
<p>Obama started in St. Francis Pre-Education from age three to five. From age six to ten, he then attended local <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Indonesian_Language" title="Indonesian Language">Indonesian-language</a> schools: <i>Sekolah Dasar Katolik Santo Fransiskus Asisi</i> (St. Francis of Assisi Catholic Elementary School) for two years and <i><a href="/wiki/State_Elementary_School_Menteng_01" title="State Elementary School Menteng 01">Sekolah Dasar Negeri Menteng 01</a></i> (State Elementary School Menteng 01/Besuki school) for one and a half years, supplemented by English-language <a href="/wiki/Calvert_School" title="Calvert School">Calvert School</a> homeschooling by his mother.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-24"><a href="#cite_note-24">[24]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-25"><a href="#cite_note-25">[25]</a></sup> As a result of those four years in <a href="/wiki/Jakarta" title="Jakarta">Jakarta</a>, he was able to speak <a href="/wiki/Indonesian_language" title="Indonesian language">Indonesian</a> fluently as a child.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-26"><a href="#cite_note-26">[26]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-in_Jakarta_27-0"><a href="#cite_note-in_Jakarta-27">[27]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-in_Jakarta2_28-0"><a href="#cite_note-in_Jakarta2-28">[28]</a></sup> During his time in Indonesia, Obama's step-father taught him to be resilient and gave him "a pretty hardheaded assessment of how the world works".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-29"><a href="#cite_note-29">[29]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1971, Obama returned to <a href="/wiki/Honolulu" title="Honolulu">Honolulu</a> to live with his maternal grandparents, <a href="/wiki/Madelyn_Dunham" title="Madelyn Dunham">Madelyn</a> and <a href="/wiki/Stanley_Armour_Dunham" title="Stanley Armour Dunham">Stanley Dunham</a>. He attended <a href="/wiki/Punahou_School" title="Punahou School">Punahou School</a>‚Äîa private <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/University-preparatory_school" title="University-preparatory school">college preparatory school</a>‚Äîwith the aid of a scholarship from fifth grade until he graduated from high school in 1979.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-30"><a href="#cite_note-30">[30]</a></sup> In his youth, Obama went by the nickname "Barry".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-31"><a href="#cite_note-31">[31]</a></sup> Obama lived with his mother and half-sister, <a href="/wiki/Maya_Soetoro-Ng" title="Maya Soetoro-Ng">Maya Soetoro</a>, in Hawaii for three years from 1972 to 1975 while his mother was a graduate student in <a href="/wiki/Anthropology" title="Anthropology">anthropology</a> at the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Hawaii" title="University of Hawaii">University of Hawaii</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-32"><a href="#cite_note-32">[32]</a></sup> Obama chose to stay in Hawaii with his grandparents for high school at <a href="/wiki/Punahou_School" title="Punahou School">Punahou</a> when his mother and half-sister returned to Indonesia in 1975 so his mother could begin anthropology field work.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-33"><a href="#cite_note-33">[33]</a></sup> His mother spent most of the next two decades in Indonesia, divorcing Lolo in 1980 and earning a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/PhD" title="PhD">PhD</a> degree in 1992, before dying in 1995 in Hawaii following unsuccessful treatment for <a href="/wiki/Ovarian_cancer" title="Ovarian cancer">ovarian</a> and <a href="/wiki/Uterine_cancer" title="Uterine cancer">uterine cancer</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-34"><a href="#cite_note-34">[34]</a></sup>
</p><p>Obama later reflected on his years in Honolulu and wrote: "The opportunity that Hawaii offered‚Äîto experience a variety of cultures in a climate of mutual respect‚Äîbecame an integral part of my world view, and a basis for the values that I hold most dear."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-35"><a href="#cite_note-35">[35]</a></sup> Obama has also written and talked about using <a href="/wiki/Alcohol_(drug)" title="Alcohol (drug)">alcohol</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Marijuana" title="Marijuana">marijuana</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Cocaine" title="Cocaine">cocaine</a> during his teenage years to "push questions of who I was out of my mind".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-36"><a href="#cite_note-36">[36]</a></sup> Obama was also a member of the "choom gang", a self-named group of friends who spent time together and occasionally smoked marijuana.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-37"><a href="#cite_note-37">[37]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-38"><a href="#cite_note-38">[38]</a></sup>
</p><p>After graduating from high school in 1979, Obama moved to <a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles" title="Los Angeles">Los Angeles</a> to attend <a href="/wiki/Occidental_College" title="Occidental College">Occidental College</a>. In February 1981, Obama made his first public speech, calling for Occidental to participate in the <a href="/wiki/Disinvestment_from_South_Africa" title="Disinvestment from South Africa">disinvestment from South Africa</a> in response to that nation's policy of <a href="/wiki/Apartheid" title="Apartheid">apartheid</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Occidental_39-0"><a href="#cite_note-Occidental-39">[39]</a></sup> In mid-1981, Obama traveled to Indonesia to visit his mother and half-sister Maya, and visited the families of college friends in <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">Pakistan</a> and <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a> for three weeks.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Occidental_39-1"><a href="#cite_note-Occidental-39">[39]</a></sup> Later in 1981, he transferred as a junior to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Columbia_College,_Columbia_University" title="Columbia College, Columbia University">Columbia University</a> in New York City, where he majored in <a href="/wiki/Political_science" title="Political science">political science</a> with a specialty in <a href="/wiki/International_relations" title="International relations">international relations</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-40"><a href="#cite_note-40">[40]</a></sup> and in <a href="/wiki/English_literature" title="English literature">English literature</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-41"><a href="#cite_note-41">[41]</a></sup> and lived off-campus on West 109th Street.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-42"><a href="#cite_note-42">[42]</a></sup> He graduated with a <a href="/wiki/Bachelor_of_Arts" title="Bachelor of Arts">BA</a> degree in 1983 and worked for about a year at the <a href="/wiki/Business_International_Corporation" title="Business International Corporation">Business International Corporation</a>, where he was a financial researcher and writer,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-43"><a href="#cite_note-43">[43]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-44"><a href="#cite_note-44">[44]</a></sup> then as a project coordinator for the <a href="/wiki/New_York_Public_Interest_Research_Group" title="New York Public Interest Research Group">New York Public Interest Research Group</a> on the <a href="/wiki/City_College_of_New_York" title="City College of New York">City College of New York</a> campus for three months in 1985.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-45"><a href="#cite_note-45">[45]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Who's_Who_2008_46-0"><a href="#cite_note-Who's_Who_2008-46">[46]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-47"><a href="#cite_note-47">[47]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Family_and_personal_life">Family and personal life</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Family_of_Barack_Obama" title="Family of Barack Obama">Family of Barack Obama</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Obama_family_portrait_in_the_Green_Room.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2731" data-file-width="4096" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Obama_family_portrait_in_the_Green_Room.jpg/220px-Obama_family_portrait_in_the_Green_Room.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Obama_family_portrait_in_the_Green_Room.jpg/330px-Obama_family_portrait_in_the_Green_Room.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Obama_family_portrait_in_the_Green_Room.jpg/440px-Obama_family_portrait_in_the_Green_Room.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Obama_family_portrait_in_the_Green_Room.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Obama poses in the <a href="/wiki/Green_Room_(White_House)" title="Green Room (White House)">Green Room</a> of the White House with wife Michelle and daughters Sasha and Malia, 2009.</div></div></div>
<p>In a 2006 interview, Obama highlighted the diversity of <a href="/wiki/Family_of_Barack_Obama" title="Family of Barack Obama">his extended family</a>: "It's like a little mini-United Nations", he said. "I've got relatives who look like <a href="/wiki/Bernie_Mac" title="Bernie Mac">Bernie Mac</a>, and I've got relatives who look like <a href="/wiki/Margaret_Thatcher" title="Margaret Thatcher">Margaret Thatcher</a>."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-48"><a href="#cite_note-48">[48]</a></sup> Obama has a half-sister with whom he was raised (Maya Soetoro-Ng) and seven other half-siblings from his Kenyan father's family‚Äîsix of them living.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-49"><a href="#cite_note-49">[49]</a></sup> Obama's mother was survived by her Kansas-born mother, <a href="/wiki/Madelyn_Dunham" title="Madelyn Dunham">Madelyn Dunham</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-50"><a href="#cite_note-50">[50]</a></sup> until her death on November 2, 2008,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-51"><a href="#cite_note-51">[51]</a></sup> two days before his election to the Presidency. Obama also has roots in Ireland; he met with his Irish cousins in <a href="/wiki/Moneygall" title="Moneygall">Moneygall</a> in May 2011.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-52"><a href="#cite_note-52">[52]</a></sup> In <i>Dreams from My Father</i>, Obama ties his mother's family history to possible Native American ancestors and distant relatives of <a href="/wiki/Jefferson_Davis" title="Jefferson Davis">Jefferson Davis</a>, <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_Confederate_States_of_America" title="President of the Confederate States of America">President of the Confederate States of America</a> during the <a href="/wiki/American_Civil_War" title="American Civil War">American Civil War</a>. He also shares distant ancestors in common with <a href="/wiki/George_W._Bush" title="George W. Bush">George W. Bush</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dick_Cheney" title="Dick Cheney">Dick Cheney</a>, among others.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-53"><a href="#cite_note-53">[53]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:BlackhawksWhiteHouse2010.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="516" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="142" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/BlackhawksWhiteHouse2010.jpg/220px-BlackhawksWhiteHouse2010.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/BlackhawksWhiteHouse2010.jpg/330px-BlackhawksWhiteHouse2010.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/BlackhawksWhiteHouse2010.jpg/440px-BlackhawksWhiteHouse2010.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:BlackhawksWhiteHouse2010.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Obama with <a href="/wiki/Jonathan_Toews" title="Jonathan Toews">Jonathan Toews</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Stanley_Cup" title="Stanley Cup">Stanley Cup</a> champion <a href="/wiki/Chicago_Blackhawks" title="Chicago Blackhawks">Chicago Blackhawks</a>, 2010</div></div></div>
<p>Obama is a supporter of the <a href="/wiki/Chicago_White_Sox" title="Chicago White Sox">Chicago White Sox</a>, and he threw out the first pitch at the <a href="/wiki/2005_American_League_Championship_Series" title="2005 American League Championship Series">2005 ALCS</a> when he was still a senator.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-54"><a href="#cite_note-54">[54]</a></sup> In 2009, he threw out the ceremonial first pitch at the <a href="/wiki/2009_Major_League_Baseball_All-Star_Game" title="2009 Major League Baseball All-Star Game">All-Star Game</a> while wearing a White Sox jacket.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-55"><a href="#cite_note-55">[55]</a></sup> He is also primarily a <a href="/wiki/Chicago_Bears" title="Chicago Bears">Chicago Bears</a> football fan in the <a href="/wiki/National_Football_League" title="National Football League">NFL</a>, but in his childhood and adolescence was a <a href="/wiki/Steeler_Nation" title="Steeler Nation">fan of the Pittsburgh Steelers</a>, and rooted for them ahead of their victory in <a href="/wiki/Super_Bowl_XLIII" title="Super Bowl XLIII">Super Bowl XLIII</a> 12 days after he took office as president.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Steelers_56-0"><a href="#cite_note-Steelers-56">[56]</a></sup> In 2011, Obama invited the <a href="/wiki/1985_Chicago_Bears_season" title="1985 Chicago Bears season">1985 Chicago Bears</a> to the White House; the team had not visited the White House after their <a href="/wiki/Super_Bowl_XX" title="Super Bowl XX">Super Bowl win</a> in 1986 due to the <a href="/wiki/Space_Shuttle_Challenger_disaster" title="Space Shuttle Challenger disaster">Space Shuttle Challenger disaster</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-57"><a href="#cite_note-57">[57]</a></sup> He plays basketball, a sport he participated in as a member of his high school's varsity team,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-58"><a href="#cite_note-58">[58]</a></sup> and he is left-handed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-59"><a href="#cite_note-59">[59]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Barack_Obama_playing_basketball_with_members_of_Congress_and_Cabinet_secretaries_2.jpg"><img alt="Obama about to take a shot while three other players look at him. One of those players attempts to block Obama." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3500" data-file-width="2333" decoding="async" height="255" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Barack_Obama_playing_basketball_with_members_of_Congress_and_Cabinet_secretaries_2.jpg/170px-Barack_Obama_playing_basketball_with_members_of_Congress_and_Cabinet_secretaries_2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Barack_Obama_playing_basketball_with_members_of_Congress_and_Cabinet_secretaries_2.jpg/255px-Barack_Obama_playing_basketball_with_members_of_Congress_and_Cabinet_secretaries_2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Barack_Obama_playing_basketball_with_members_of_Congress_and_Cabinet_secretaries_2.jpg/340px-Barack_Obama_playing_basketball_with_members_of_Congress_and_Cabinet_secretaries_2.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Barack_Obama_playing_basketball_with_members_of_Congress_and_Cabinet_secretaries_2.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Obama takes a left-handed <a href="/wiki/Jump_shot_(basketball)" title="Jump shot (basketball)">jump shot</a> during a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pickup_game" title="Pickup game">pickup game</a> on the White House basketball court, 2009.</div></div></div>
<p>Obama lived with anthropologist <a href="/wiki/Sheila_Miyoshi_Jager" title="Sheila Miyoshi Jager">Sheila Miyoshi Jager</a> while he was a community organizer in Chicago in the 1980s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-theindependentbeforemichelle_60-0"><a href="#cite_note-theindependentbeforemichelle-60">[60]</a></sup> He proposed to her twice, but both Jager and her parents turned him down.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-theindependentbeforemichelle_60-1"><a href="#cite_note-theindependentbeforemichelle-60">[60]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tobiasoberlincollegeprofessor_61-0"><a href="#cite_note-tobiasoberlincollegeprofessor-61">[61]</a></sup> The relationship was not made public until May 2017, several months after his presidency had ended.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tobiasoberlincollegeprofessor_61-1"><a href="#cite_note-tobiasoberlincollegeprofessor-61">[61]</a></sup>
</p><p>In June 1989, Obama met <a href="/wiki/Michelle_Obama" title="Michelle Obama">Michelle Robinson</a> when he was employed as a summer associate at the Chicago law firm of <a href="/wiki/Sidley_Austin" title="Sidley Austin">Sidley Austin</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-62"><a href="#cite_note-62">[62]</a></sup> Robinson was assigned for three months as Obama's adviser at the firm, and she joined him at several group social functions but declined his initial requests to date.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-63"><a href="#cite_note-63">[63]</a></sup> They began dating later that summer, became engaged in 1991, and were married on October 3, 1992.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-64"><a href="#cite_note-64">[64]</a></sup> After suffering a miscarriage, Michelle underwent <a href="/wiki/In_vitro_fertilisation" title="In vitro fertilisation">in vitro fertilisation</a> to conceive their children.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-65"><a href="#cite_note-65">[65]</a></sup> The couple's first daughter, Malia Ann, was born in 1998,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-66"><a href="#cite_note-66">[66]</a></sup> followed by a second daughter, Natasha ("Sasha"), in 2001.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-67"><a href="#cite_note-67">[67]</a></sup> The Obama daughters attended the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Chicago_Laboratory_Schools" title="University of Chicago Laboratory Schools">University of Chicago Laboratory Schools</a>. When they moved to Washington, D.C., in January 2009, the girls started at the <a href="/wiki/Sidwell_Friends_School" title="Sidwell Friends School">Sidwell Friends School</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-68"><a href="#cite_note-68">[68]</a></sup> The Obamas have two <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Water_Dog" title="Portuguese Water Dog">Portuguese Water Dogs</a>; the first, a male named <a href="/wiki/Bo_(dog)" title="Bo (dog)">Bo</a>, was a gift from Senator <a href="/wiki/Ted_Kennedy" title="Ted Kennedy">Ted Kennedy</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-69"><a href="#cite_note-69">[69]</a></sup> In 2013, Bo was joined by <a href="/wiki/Sunny_(dog)" title="Sunny (dog)">Sunny</a>, a female.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Feldmann_70-0"><a href="#cite_note-Feldmann-70">[70]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:DIG13623-230.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3100" data-file-width="2796" decoding="async" height="188" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/DIG13623-230.jpg/170px-DIG13623-230.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/DIG13623-230.jpg/255px-DIG13623-230.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/DIG13623-230.jpg/340px-DIG13623-230.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:DIG13623-230.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Obama and his wife Michelle at the Civil Rights Summit at the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/LBJ_Presidential_Library" title="LBJ Presidential Library">LBJ Presidential Library</a>, 2014</div></div></div>
<p>In 2005, the family applied the proceeds of a book deal and moved from a <a href="/wiki/Hyde_Park,_Chicago" title="Hyde Park, Chicago">Hyde Park, Chicago</a> condominium to a $1.6¬†million house (equivalent to $2.1¬†million in 2018) in neighboring <a href="/wiki/Kenwood,_Chicago" title="Kenwood, Chicago">Kenwood, Chicago</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-71"><a href="#cite_note-71">[71]</a></sup> The purchase of an adjacent lot‚Äîand sale of part of it to Obama by the wife of developer, campaign donor and friend <a href="/wiki/Tony_Rezko" title="Tony Rezko">Tony Rezko</a>‚Äîattracted media attention because of Rezko's subsequent indictment and conviction on political corruption charges that were unrelated to Obama.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-corruption_charges_72-0"><a href="#cite_note-corruption_charges-72">[72]</a></sup>
</p><p>In December 2007, <i><a href="/wiki/Money_(magazine)" title="Money (magazine)">Money Magazine</a></i> estimated Obama's net worth at $1.3¬†million (equivalent to $1.6¬†million in 2018) .<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-73"><a href="#cite_note-73">[73]</a></sup> Their 2009 tax return showed a household income of $5.5¬†million‚Äîup from about $4.2¬†million in 2007 and $1.6¬†million in 2005‚Äîmostly from sales of his books.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-74"><a href="#cite_note-74">[74]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-75"><a href="#cite_note-75">[75]</a></sup> On his 2010 income of $1.7¬†million, he gave 14% to non-profit organizations, including $131,000 to <a href="/wiki/Fisher_House_Foundation" title="Fisher House Foundation">Fisher House Foundation</a>, a charity assisting wounded veterans' families, allowing them to reside near where the veteran is receiving medical treatments.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-76"><a href="#cite_note-76">[76]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-77"><a href="#cite_note-77">[77]</a></sup> Per his 2012 financial disclosure, Obama may be worth as much as $10¬†million.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-networth12_78-0"><a href="#cite_note-networth12-78">[78]</a></sup>
</p><p>In early 2010, Michelle spoke about her husband's smoking habit and said Barack had quit smoking.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-reuters-smoking_79-0"><a href="#cite_note-reuters-smoking-79">[79]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-80"><a href="#cite_note-80">[80]</a></sup>
</p><p>On his 55th birthday, August 4, 2016, Obama penned an essay in <a href="/wiki/Glamour_(magazine)" title="Glamour (magazine)"><i>Glamour</i></a>, in which he described how his daughters and the presidency have made him a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Feminist" title="Feminist">feminist</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-81"><a href="#cite_note-81">[81]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-82"><a href="#cite_note-82">[82]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-83"><a href="#cite_note-83">[83]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Religious_views">Religious views</span></h4>
<p>Obama is a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Protestant" title="Protestant">Protestant</a> Christian whose religious views developed in his adult life.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Christian_84-0"><a href="#cite_note-Christian-84">[84]</a></sup> He wrote in <i><a href="/wiki/The_Audacity_of_Hope" title="The Audacity of Hope">The Audacity of Hope</a></i> that he "was not raised in a religious household". He described his mother, raised by non-religious parents, as being detached from religion, yet "in many ways the most spiritually awakened person<span class="nowrap">¬†</span>... I have ever known". He described his father as a "confirmed <a href="/wiki/Atheism" title="Atheism">atheist</a>" by the time his parents met, and his stepfather as "a man who saw religion as not particularly useful". Obama explained how, through working with <a href="/wiki/Black_church" title="Black church">black churches</a> as a <a href="/wiki/Community_organizing" title="Community organizing">community organizer</a> while in his twenties, he came to understand "the power of the African-American religious tradition to spur social change."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-social_change_85-0"><a href="#cite_note-social_change-85">[85]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Obamas_at_church_on_Inauguration_Day_2013.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2675" data-file-width="4040" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Obamas_at_church_on_Inauguration_Day_2013.jpg/220px-Obamas_at_church_on_Inauguration_Day_2013.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Obamas_at_church_on_Inauguration_Day_2013.jpg/330px-Obamas_at_church_on_Inauguration_Day_2013.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Obamas_at_church_on_Inauguration_Day_2013.jpg/440px-Obamas_at_church_on_Inauguration_Day_2013.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Obamas_at_church_on_Inauguration_Day_2013.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The Obamas worship at <a href="/wiki/African_Methodist_Episcopal_Church" title="African Methodist Episcopal Church">African Methodist Episcopal Church</a> in Washington, D.C., January 2013.</div></div></div>
<p>In January 2008, Obama told <i><a href="/wiki/Christianity_Today" title="Christianity Today">Christianity Today</a></i>: "I am a Christian, and I am a devout Christian. I believe in the <a href="/wiki/Redeemer_(Christianity)" title="Redeemer (Christianity)">redemptive death</a> and <a href="/wiki/Resurrection_of_Jesus" title="Resurrection of Jesus">resurrection of Jesus</a> Christ. I believe that faith gives me a path to be cleansed of sin and have eternal life."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-86"><a href="#cite_note-86">[86]</a></sup> On September 27, 2010, Obama released a statement commenting on his religious views saying, "I'm a Christian by choice. My family didn't‚Äîfrankly, they weren't folks who went to church every week. And my mother was one of the most spiritual people I knew, but she didn't raise me in the church. So I came to my Christian faith later in life, and it was because the precepts of Jesus Christ spoke to me in terms of the kind of life that I would want to lead‚Äîbeing my brothers' and sisters' keeper, <a href="/wiki/Golden_Rule" title="Golden Rule">treating others as they would treat me</a>."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-APbychoice_87-0"><a href="#cite_note-APbychoice-87">[87]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ABCVideobychoice_88-0"><a href="#cite_note-ABCVideobychoice-88">[88]</a></sup>
</p><p>Obama met <a href="/wiki/Trinity_United_Church_of_Christ" title="Trinity United Church of Christ">Trinity United Church of Christ</a> pastor <a href="/wiki/Jeremiah_Wright" title="Jeremiah Wright">Jeremiah Wright</a> in October 1987 and became a member of Trinity in 1992.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Trinity_89-0"><a href="#cite_note-Trinity-89">[89]</a></sup> During Obama's first presidential campaign in May 2008, he resigned from Trinity after <a href="/wiki/Jeremiah_Wright_controversy" title="Jeremiah Wright controversy">some of Wright's statements were criticized</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-90"><a href="#cite_note-90">[90]</a></sup> Since moving to Washington, D.C., in 2009, the Obama family has attended several Protestant churches, including <a href="/wiki/Shiloh_Baptist_Church_(Washington,_D.C.)" title="Shiloh Baptist Church (Washington, D.C.)">Shiloh Baptist Church</a> and <a href="/wiki/St._John%27s_Episcopal_Church,_Lafayette_Square" title="St. John's Episcopal Church, Lafayette Square">St. John's Episcopal Church</a>, as well as Evergreen Chapel at <a href="/wiki/Camp_David" title="Camp David">Camp David</a>, but the members of the family do not attend church on a regular basis.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-91"><a href="#cite_note-91">[91]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-92"><a href="#cite_note-92">[92]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-93"><a href="#cite_note-93">[93]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Law_career">Law career</span></h3>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Community_organizer_and_Harvard_Law_School">Community organizer and Harvard Law School</span></h4>
<p>Two years after graduating from Columbia, Obama moved from New York to Chicago when he was hired as director of the <a href="/wiki/Developing_Communities_Project" title="Developing Communities Project">Developing Communities Project</a>, a church-based community organization originally comprising eight Catholic parishes in <a href="/wiki/Roseland,_Chicago" title="Roseland, Chicago">Roseland</a>, <a href="/wiki/West_Pullman,_Chicago" title="West Pullman, Chicago">West Pullman</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Riverdale,_Chicago" title="Riverdale, Chicago">Riverdale</a> on Chicago's <a href="/wiki/South_Side,_Chicago" title="South Side, Chicago">South Side</a>. He worked there as a community organizer from June 1985 to May 1988.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Who's_Who_2008_46-1"><a href="#cite_note-Who's_Who_2008-46">[46]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-94"><a href="#cite_note-94">[94]</a></sup> He helped set up a job training program, a college preparatory tutoring program, and a tenants' rights organization in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Altgeld_Gardens_Homes_(Chicago,_Illinois)" title="Altgeld Gardens Homes (Chicago, Illinois)">Altgeld Gardens</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Harvard_Law_1990a_95-0"><a href="#cite_note-Harvard_Law_1990a-95">[95]</a></sup> Obama also worked as a consultant and instructor for the <a href="/wiki/Gamaliel_Foundation" title="Gamaliel Foundation">Gamaliel Foundation</a>, a community organizing institute.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-96"><a href="#cite_note-96">[96]</a></sup> In mid-1988, he traveled for the first time in Europe for three weeks and then for five weeks in Kenya, where he met many of his <a href="/wiki/Family_of_Barack_Obama#Paternal_relations" title="Family of Barack Obama">paternal relatives</a> for the first time.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Obama_2012_97-0"><a href="#cite_note-Obama_2012-97">[97]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-98"><a href="#cite_note-98">[98]</a></sup>
</p>
<table class="infobox" style="width:22em;float: right; clear: right; margin:0 0 1.5em 1.5em"><caption>External video</caption><tbody><tr><td colspan="2" style="text-align:center;text-align: left"><img alt="" data-file-height="128" data-file-width="128" decoding="async" height="16" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Nuvola_apps_kaboodle.svg/16px-Nuvola_apps_kaboodle.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Nuvola_apps_kaboodle.svg/24px-Nuvola_apps_kaboodle.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Nuvola_apps_kaboodle.svg/32px-Nuvola_apps_kaboodle.svg.png 2x" width="16"/> <a class="external text" href="http://bostonlocaltv.org/catalog/V_UDAMVZGA4JEY06N" rel="nofollow">Derrick Bell threatens to leave Harvard</a>, April 24, 1990, 11:34, <a href="/wiki/WGBH_Educational_Foundation" title="WGBH Educational Foundation">Boston TV Digital Archive</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wgbh_99-0"><a href="#cite_note-wgbh-99">[99]</a></sup> Student Barack Obama introduces Professor Derrick Bell starting at 6:25.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Despite being offered a full scholarship to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Northwestern_University_School_of_Law" title="Northwestern University School of Law">Northwestern University School of Law</a>, Obama enrolled at <a href="/wiki/Harvard_Law_School" title="Harvard Law School">Harvard Law School</a> in the fall of 1988, living in nearby <a href="/wiki/Somerville,_Massachusetts" title="Somerville, Massachusetts">Somerville, Massachusetts</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-100"><a href="#cite_note-100">[100]</a></sup> He was selected as an editor of the <i><a href="/wiki/Harvard_Law_Review" title="Harvard Law Review">Harvard Law Review</a></i> at the end of his first year,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Harvard_Law_2007_101-0"><a href="#cite_note-Harvard_Law_2007-101">[101]</a></sup> president of the journal in his second year,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Harvard_Law_1990a_95-1"><a href="#cite_note-Harvard_Law_1990a-95">[95]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Harvard_Law_1990b_102-0"><a href="#cite_note-Harvard_Law_1990b-102">[102]</a></sup> and research assistant to the constitutional scholar <a href="/wiki/Laurence_Tribe" title="Laurence Tribe">Laurence Tribe</a> while at Harvard for two years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-103"><a href="#cite_note-103">[103]</a></sup> During his summers, he returned to Chicago, where he worked as a <a href="/wiki/Associate_attorney#Summer_associates" title="Associate attorney">summer associate</a> at the law firms of <a href="/wiki/Sidley_Austin" title="Sidley Austin">Sidley Austin</a> in 1989 and <a href="/wiki/Hopkins_%26_Sutter" title="Hopkins &amp; Sutter">Hopkins &amp; Sutter</a> in 1990.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-104"><a href="#cite_note-104">[104]</a></sup> After graduating with a <a href="/wiki/Juris_Doctor" title="Juris Doctor">JD</a> degree <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Magna_cum_laude" title="Magna cum laude">magna cum laude</a></i><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Juris_Doctor_105-0"><a href="#cite_note-Juris_Doctor-105">[105]</a></sup> from Harvard in 1991, he returned to Chicago.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Harvard_Law_2007_101-1"><a href="#cite_note-Harvard_Law_2007-101">[101]</a></sup> Obama's election as the <a href="/wiki/List_of_African-American_firsts" title="List of African-American firsts">first black president of the <i>Harvard Law Review</i></a> gained national media attention<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Harvard_Law_1990a_95-2"><a href="#cite_note-Harvard_Law_1990a-95">[95]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Harvard_Law_1990b_102-1"><a href="#cite_note-Harvard_Law_1990b-102">[102]</a></sup> and led to a publishing contract and advance for a book about race relations,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Scott_2008a_106-0"><a href="#cite_note-Scott_2008a-106">[106]</a></sup> which evolved into a personal memoir. The manuscript was published in mid-1995 as <i><a href="/wiki/Dreams_from_My_Father" title="Dreams from My Father">Dreams from My Father</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Scott_2008a_106-1"><a href="#cite_note-Scott_2008a-106">[106]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Chicago_Law_School_and_civil_rights_attorney">Chicago Law School and civil rights attorney</span></h4>
<p>In 1991, Obama accepted a two-year position as Visiting Law and Government Fellow at the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Chicago_Law_School" title="University of Chicago Law School">University of Chicago Law School</a> to work on his first book.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Scott_2008a_106-2"><a href="#cite_note-Scott_2008a-106">[106]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Fellow_107-0"><a href="#cite_note-Fellow-107">[107]</a></sup> He then taught <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_law" title="Constitutional law">constitutional law</a> at the University of Chicago Law School for twelve years, first as a <a href="/wiki/Lecturer" title="Lecturer">lecturer</a> from 1992 to 1996, and then as a senior lecturer from 1996 to 2004.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-108"><a href="#cite_note-108">[108]</a></sup>
</p><p>From April to October 1992, Obama directed Illinois's <a href="/wiki/Project_Vote" title="Project Vote">Project Vote</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Voter_registration_campaign" title="Voter registration campaign">voter registration campaign</a> with ten staffers and seven hundred volunteer registrars; it achieved its goal of registering 150,000 of 400,000 unregistered African Americans in the state, leading <i><a href="/wiki/Crain%27s_Chicago_Business" title="Crain's Chicago Business">Crain's Chicago Business</a></i> to name Obama to its 1993 list of "40 under Forty" powers to be.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Forty_109-0"><a href="#cite_note-Forty-109">[109]</a></sup>
</p><p>He joined Davis, Miner, Barnhill &amp; Galland, a 13-attorney law firm specializing in civil rights litigation and neighborhood economic development, where he was an <a href="/wiki/Associate_attorney" title="Associate attorney">associate</a> for three years from 1993 to 1996, then <a href="/wiki/Of_counsel" title="Of counsel">of counsel</a> from 1996 to 2004. In 1994, he was listed as one of the lawyers in <i>Buycks-Roberson v. Citibank Fed. Sav. Bank</i>, 94 C 4094 (N.D. Ill.).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-110"><a href="#cite_note-110">[110]</a></sup> This <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Class-action_lawsuit" title="Class-action lawsuit">class action lawsuit</a> was filed in 1994 with Selma Buycks-Roberson as lead plaintiff and alleged that Citibank Federal Savings Bank had engaged in practices forbidden under the <a href="/wiki/Equal_Credit_Opportunity_Act" title="Equal Credit Opportunity Act">Equal Credit Opportunity Act</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fair_Housing_Act" title="Fair Housing Act">Fair Housing Act</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-111"><a href="#cite_note-111">[111]</a></sup> The case was settled out of court.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-112"><a href="#cite_note-112">[112]</a></sup> Final judgment was issued on May 13, 1998, with Citibank Federal Savings Bank agreeing to pay attorney fees.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-113"><a href="#cite_note-113">[113]</a></sup> His law license became inactive in 2007.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-114"><a href="#cite_note-114">[114]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DavisMiner_115-0"><a href="#cite_note-DavisMiner-115">[115]</a></sup>
</p><p>From 1994 to 2002, Obama served on the boards of directors of the <a href="/wiki/Woods_Fund_of_Chicago" title="Woods Fund of Chicago">Woods Fund of Chicago</a>‚Äîwhich in 1985 had been the first foundation to fund the Developing Communities Project‚Äîand of the <a href="/wiki/Joyce_Foundation" title="Joyce Foundation">Joyce Foundation</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Who's_Who_2008_46-2"><a href="#cite_note-Who's_Who_2008-46">[46]</a></sup> He served on the board of directors of the <a href="/wiki/Chicago_Annenberg_Challenge" title="Chicago Annenberg Challenge">Chicago Annenberg Challenge</a> from 1995 to 2002, as founding president and chairman of the board of directors from 1995 to 1999.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Who's_Who_2008_46-3"><a href="#cite_note-Who's_Who_2008-46">[46]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Legislative_career">Legislative career</span></h3>
<h4><span id="Illinois_State_Senator_.281997.E2.80.932004.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Illinois_State_Senator_(1997‚Äì2004)">Illinois State Senator (1997‚Äì2004)</span></h4>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Illinois_Senate_career_of_Barack_Obama" title="Illinois Senate career of Barack Obama">Illinois Senate career of Barack Obama</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Obamamiltondavis1.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="450" data-file-width="489" decoding="async" height="202" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Obamamiltondavis1.jpg/220px-Obamamiltondavis1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Obamamiltondavis1.jpg/330px-Obamamiltondavis1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Obamamiltondavis1.jpg/440px-Obamamiltondavis1.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Obamamiltondavis1.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>State Senator Obama and others celebrate the naming of a street in Chicago after <a href="/wiki/ShoreBank" title="ShoreBank">ShoreBank</a> co-founder Milton Davis in 1998.</div></div></div>
<p>Obama was elected to the <a href="/wiki/Illinois_Senate" title="Illinois Senate">Illinois Senate</a> in 1996, succeeding Democratic State Senator <a href="/wiki/Alice_Palmer_(politician)" title="Alice Palmer (politician)">Alice Palmer</a> from Illinois's 13th District, which, at that time, spanned Chicago South Side neighborhoods from <a href="/wiki/Hyde_Park,_Chicago" title="Hyde Park, Chicago">Hyde Park</a>‚Äì<a href="/wiki/Kenwood,_Chicago" title="Kenwood, Chicago">Kenwood</a> south to <a href="/wiki/South_Shore,_Chicago" title="South Shore, Chicago">South Shore</a> and west to <a href="/wiki/Chicago_Lawn,_Chicago" title="Chicago Lawn, Chicago">Chicago Lawn</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-116"><a href="#cite_note-116">[116]</a></sup> Once elected, Obama gained bipartisan support for legislation that reformed ethics and health care laws.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-117"><a href="#cite_note-117">[117]</a></sup> He sponsored a law that increased <a href="/wiki/Tax_credit" title="Tax credit">tax credits</a> for low-income workers, negotiated <a href="/wiki/Welfare_reform" title="Welfare reform">welfare reform</a>, and promoted increased subsidies for childcare.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Scott20070730_118-0"><a href="#cite_note-Scott20070730-118">[118]</a></sup> In 2001, as co-chairman of the bipartisan Joint Committee on Administrative Rules, Obama supported Republican Governor Ryan's <a href="/wiki/Payday_loan" title="Payday loan">payday loan</a> regulations and <a href="/wiki/Predatory_lending" title="Predatory lending">predatory mortgage lending</a> regulations aimed at averting home <a href="/wiki/Foreclosure" title="Foreclosure">foreclosures</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-119"><a href="#cite_note-119">[119]</a></sup>
</p><p>He was reelected to the Illinois Senate in 1998, defeating Republican Yesse Yehudah in the general election, and was re-elected again in 2002.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-120"><a href="#cite_note-120">[120]</a></sup> In 2000, he lost a <a href="/wiki/2000_Illinois%27s_1st_congressional_district_election" title="2000 Illinois's 1st congressional district election">Democratic primary race</a> for <a href="/wiki/Illinois%27s_1st_congressional_district" title="Illinois's 1st congressional district">Illinois's 1st congressional district</a> in the <a href="/wiki/United_States_House_of_Representatives" title="United States House of Representatives">United States House of Representatives</a> to four-term incumbent <a href="/wiki/Bobby_Rush" title="Bobby Rush">Bobby Rush</a> by a margin of two to one.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Democratic_primary_121-0"><a href="#cite_note-Democratic_primary-121">[121]</a></sup>
</p><p>In January 2003, Obama became chairman of the Illinois Senate's Health and Human Services Committee when Democrats, after a decade in the minority, regained a majority.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-122"><a href="#cite_note-122">[122]</a></sup> He sponsored and led unanimous, bipartisan passage of legislation to monitor <a href="/wiki/Racial_profiling" title="Racial profiling">racial profiling</a> by requiring police to record the race of drivers they detained, and legislation making Illinois the first state to mandate videotaping of homicide interrogations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Scott20070730_118-1"><a href="#cite_note-Scott20070730-118">[118]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-123"><a href="#cite_note-123">[123]</a></sup> During his 2004 general election campaign for the U.S. Senate, police representatives credited Obama for his active engagement with police organizations in enacting <a href="/wiki/Capital_punishment_in_the_United_States" title="Capital punishment in the United States">death penalty</a> reforms.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-124"><a href="#cite_note-124">[124]</a></sup> Obama resigned from the Illinois Senate in November 2004 following his election to the U.S. Senate.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-125"><a href="#cite_note-125">[125]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="2004_U.S._Senate_campaign">2004 U.S. Senate campaign</span></h4>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/2004_United_States_Senate_election_in_Illinois" title="2004 United States Senate election in Illinois">2004 United States Senate election in Illinois</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Illinois_Senate_Election_Results_by_County,_2004.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="337" data-file-width="187" decoding="async" height="234" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Illinois_Senate_Election_Results_by_County%2C_2004.svg/130px-Illinois_Senate_Election_Results_by_County%2C_2004.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Illinois_Senate_Election_Results_by_County%2C_2004.svg/195px-Illinois_Senate_Election_Results_by_County%2C_2004.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Illinois_Senate_Election_Results_by_County%2C_2004.svg/260px-Illinois_Senate_Election_Results_by_County%2C_2004.svg.png 2x" width="130"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Illinois_Senate_Election_Results_by_County,_2004.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Results of the 2004 U.S. Senate race in Illinois; Obama won the counties in blue.</div></div></div>
<p>In May 2002, Obama commissioned a poll to assess his prospects in a 2004 U.S. Senate race. He created a campaign committee, began raising funds, and lined up political media consultant <a href="/wiki/David_Axelrod_(political_consultant)" title="David Axelrod (political consultant)">David Axelrod</a> by August 2002. Obama formally announced his candidacy in January 2003.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-126"><a href="#cite_note-126">[126]</a></sup>
</p><p>Obama was an early opponent of the <a href="/wiki/George_W._Bush" title="George W. Bush">George W. Bush</a> administration's <a href="/wiki/2003_invasion_of_Iraq" title="2003 invasion of Iraq">2003 invasion of Iraq</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-127"><a href="#cite_note-127">[127]</a></sup> On October 2, 2002, the day President Bush and Congress agreed on the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Iraq_Resolution" title="Iraq Resolution">joint resolution</a> authorizing the <a href="/wiki/Iraq_War" title="Iraq War">Iraq War</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Rose_Garden_128-0"><a href="#cite_note-Rose_Garden-128">[128]</a></sup> Obama addressed the first high-profile Chicago <a href="/wiki/Protests_against_the_Iraq_War" title="Protests against the Iraq War">anti-Iraq War rally</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Federal_Plaza_129-0"><a href="#cite_note-Federal_Plaza-129">[129]</a></sup> and spoke out against the war.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-spoke_out_130-0"><a href="#cite_note-spoke_out-130">[130]</a></sup> He addressed another anti-war rally in March 2003 and told the crowd "it's not too late" to stop the war.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-stop_the_war_131-0"><a href="#cite_note-stop_the_war-131">[131]</a></sup>
</p><p>Decisions by Republican incumbent <a href="/wiki/Peter_Fitzgerald_(politician)" title="Peter Fitzgerald (politician)">Peter Fitzgerald</a> and his Democratic predecessor <a href="/wiki/Carol_Moseley_Braun" title="Carol Moseley Braun">Carol Moseley Braun</a> to not participate in the election resulted in wide-open Democratic and Republican primary contests involving 15 candidates.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-132"><a href="#cite_note-132">[132]</a></sup> In the March 2004 primary election, Obama won in an unexpected landslide‚Äîwhich overnight made him a rising star within the <a href="/wiki/Democratic_National_Committee" title="Democratic National Committee">national Democratic Party</a>, started speculation about a presidential future, and led to the reissue of his memoir, <i>Dreams from My Father</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-future_133-0"><a href="#cite_note-future-133">[133]</a></sup> In July 2004, Obama delivered the keynote address at the <a href="/wiki/2004_Democratic_National_Convention" title="2004 Democratic National Convention">2004 Democratic National Convention</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-134"><a href="#cite_note-134">[134]</a></sup> seen by nine million viewers. His speech was well received and elevated his status within the Democratic Party.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-status_135-0"><a href="#cite_note-status-135">[135]</a></sup>
</p><p>Obama's expected opponent in the general election, Republican primary winner <a href="/wiki/Jack_Ryan_(politician)" title="Jack Ryan (politician)">Jack Ryan</a>, withdrew from the race in June 2004.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-136"><a href="#cite_note-136">[136]</a></sup> Six weeks later, <a href="/wiki/Alan_Keyes" title="Alan Keyes">Alan Keyes</a> accepted the Republican nomination to replace Ryan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-137"><a href="#cite_note-137">[137]</a></sup> In the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_States_Senate_election_in_Illinois,_2004" title="United States Senate election in Illinois, 2004">November 2004 general election</a>, Obama won with 70% of the vote.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-margin_138-0"><a href="#cite_note-margin-138">[138]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span id="U.S._Senator_from_Illinois_.282005.E2.80.9308.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="U.S._Senator_from_Illinois_(2005‚Äì08)">U.S. Senator from Illinois (2005‚Äì08)</span></h4>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/United_States_Senate_career_of_Barack_Obama" title="United States Senate career of Barack Obama">United States Senate career of Barack Obama</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:BarackObamaportrait.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="6000" data-file-width="4800" decoding="async" height="213" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f1/BarackObamaportrait.jpg/170px-BarackObamaportrait.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f1/BarackObamaportrait.jpg/255px-BarackObamaportrait.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f1/BarackObamaportrait.jpg/340px-BarackObamaportrait.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:BarackObamaportrait.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Official portrait of Obama as a member of the United States Senate</div></div></div>
<p>Obama was sworn in as a senator on January 3, 2005,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-139"><a href="#cite_note-139">[139]</a></sup> becoming the only Senate member of the <a href="/wiki/Congressional_Black_Caucus" title="Congressional Black Caucus">Congressional Black Caucus</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-140"><a href="#cite_note-140">[140]</a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/Congressional_Quarterly" title="Congressional Quarterly">CQ Weekly</a></i> characterized him as a "loyal Democrat" based on analysis of all Senate votes from 2005 to 2007. Obama announced on November 13, 2008, that he would <a href="/wiki/Resignation_from_the_United_States_Senate" title="Resignation from the United States Senate">resign his Senate seat</a> on November 16, 2008, before the start of the <a href="/wiki/Lame_duck_(politics)" title="Lame duck (politics)">lame-duck</a> session, to focus on his transition period for the presidency.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-transition_period_141-0"><a href="#cite_note-transition_period-141">[141]</a></sup>
</p>
<h5><span class="mw-headline" id="Legislation">Legislation</span></h5>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_bills_sponsored_by_Barack_Obama_in_the_United_States_Senate" title="List of bills sponsored by Barack Obama in the United States Senate">List of bills sponsored by Barack Obama in the United States Senate</a></div>
<p>Obama <a href="/wiki/Sponsor_(legislative)" title="Sponsor (legislative)">cosponsored</a> the <a href="/wiki/Secure_America_and_Orderly_Immigration_Act" title="Secure America and Orderly Immigration Act">Secure America and Orderly Immigration Act</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-142"><a href="#cite_note-142">[142]</a></sup> He introduced two initiatives that bore his name: Lugar‚ÄìObama, which expanded the <a href="/wiki/Nunn%E2%80%93Lugar_Cooperative_Threat_Reduction" title="Nunn‚ÄìLugar Cooperative Threat Reduction">Nunn‚ÄìLugar Cooperative Threat Reduction</a> concept to conventional weapons;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-143"><a href="#cite_note-143">[143]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Federal_Funding_Accountability_and_Transparency_Act_of_2006" title="Federal Funding Accountability and Transparency Act of 2006">Federal Funding Accountability and Transparency Act of 2006</a>, which authorized the establishment of USAspending.gov, a web search engine on federal spending.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-144"><a href="#cite_note-144">[144]</a></sup> On June 3, 2008, Senator Obama‚Äîalong with Senators <a href="/wiki/Tom_Carper" title="Tom Carper">Tom Carper</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tom_Coburn" title="Tom Coburn">Tom Coburn</a>, and <a href="/wiki/John_McCain" title="John McCain">John McCain</a>‚Äîintroduced follow-up legislation: Strengthening Transparency and Accountability in Federal Spending Act of 2008.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-145"><a href="#cite_note-145">[145]</a></sup>
</p><p>Obama sponsored legislation that would have required nuclear plant owners to notify state and local authorities of radioactive leaks, but the bill failed to pass in the full Senate after being heavily modified in committee.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-146"><a href="#cite_note-146">[146]</a></sup> Regarding <a href="/wiki/Tort_reform" title="Tort reform">tort reform</a>, Obama voted for the <a href="/wiki/Class_Action_Fairness_Act_of_2005" title="Class Action Fairness Act of 2005">Class Action Fairness Act of 2005</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Foreign_Intelligence_Surveillance_Act_of_1978_Amendments_Act_of_2008" title="Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978 Amendments Act of 2008">FISA Amendments Act of 2008</a>, which grants immunity from civil liability to telecommunications companies complicit with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/NSA_warrantless_surveillance_(2001%E2%80%9307)" title="NSA warrantless surveillance (2001‚Äì07)">NSA warrantless wiretapping</a> operations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Fisher_147-0"><a href="#cite_note-Fisher-147">[147]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Lugar-Obama.jpg"><img alt="Gray-haired man and Obama stand, wearing casual polo shirts.
