codecs=&amp;quot;vp9, opus&amp;quot;" data-title="Lowest bandwidth VP9 (120P)" data-shorttitle="VP9 120P" data-transcodekey="120p.vp9.webm" data-width="214" data-height="120" data-bandwidth="124792" data-framerate="29.97"/&gt;&lt;source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/a/a5/20090124_WeeklyAddress.ogv/20090124_WeeklyAddress.ogv.160p.webm" type="video/webm; codecs=&amp;quot;vp8, vorbis&amp;quot;" data-title="Low bandwidth WebM (160P)" data-shorttitle="WebM 160P" data-transcodekey="160p.webm" data-width="284" data-height="160" data-bandwidth="195552" data-framerate="29.97"/&gt;&lt;source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/a/a5/20090124_WeeklyAddress.ogv/20090124_WeeklyAddress.ogv.180p.vp9.webm" type="video/webm; codecs=&amp;quot;vp9, opus&amp;quot;" data-title="Low bandwidth VP9 (180P)" data-shorttitle="VP9 180P" data-transcodekey="180p.vp9.webm" data-width="320" data-height="180" data-bandwidth="157040" data-framerate="29.97"/&gt;&lt;source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/a/a5/20090124_WeeklyAddress.ogv/20090124_WeeklyAddress.ogv.240p.vp9.webm" type="video/webm; codecs=&amp;quot;vp9, opus&amp;quot;" data-title="Small VP9 (240P)" data-shorttitle="VP9 240P" data-transcodekey="240p.vp9.webm" data-width="426" data-height="240" data-bandwidth="186888" data-framerate="29.97"/&gt;&lt;source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/a/a5/20090124_WeeklyAddress.ogv/20090124_WeeklyAddress.ogv.240p.webm" type="video/webm; codecs=&amp;quot;vp8, vorbis&amp;quot;" data-title="Small WebM (240P)" data-shorttitle="WebM 240P" data-transcodekey="240p.webm" data-width="426" data-height="240" data-bandwidth="317456" data-framerate="29.97"/&gt;&lt;source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/a/a5/20090124_WeeklyAddress.ogv/20090124_WeeklyAddress.ogv.360p.vp9.webm" type="video/webm; codecs=&amp;quot;vp9, opus&amp;quot;" data-title="VP9 (360P)" data-shorttitle="VP9 360P" data-transcodekey="360p.vp9.webm" data-width="640" data-height="360" data-bandwidth="287984" data-framerate="29.97"/&gt;&lt;source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/a/a5/20090124_WeeklyAddress.ogv/20090124_WeeklyAddress.ogv.360p.webm" type="video/webm; codecs=&amp;quot;vp8, vorbis&amp;quot;" data-title="WebM (360P)" data-shorttitle="WebM 360P" data-transcodekey="360p.webm" data-width="640" data-height="360" data-bandwidth="577032" data-framerate="29.97"/&gt;&lt;track src="https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/api.php?action=timedtext&amp;amp;title=File%3A20090124_WeeklyAddress.ogv&amp;amp;lang=en&amp;amp;trackformat=srt&amp;amp;origin=%2A" kind="subtitles" type="text/x-srt" srclang="en" label="English (en) subtitles" data-dir="ltr"/&gt;&lt;/video&gt;&lt;/div&gt;'><img alt="File:20090124 WeeklyAddress.ogv" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/20090124_WeeklyAddress.ogv/220px-seek%3D63-20090124_WeeklyAddress.ogv.jpg" style="width:220px;height:124px"/><a href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/a5/20090124_WeeklyAddress.ogv" target="new" title="Play media"><span class="play-btn-large"><span class="mw-tmh-playtext">Play media</span></span></a></div> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:20090124_WeeklyAddress.ogv" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Obama presents his first <a class="extiw" href="https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Obama_Administration_weekly_video_addresses" title="commons:Obama Administration weekly video addresses">weekly address</a> as President of the United States on January 24, 2009, discussing the <a href="/wiki/American_Recovery_and_Reinvestment_Act_of_2009" title="American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009">American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009</a></div></div></div>
<p>On February 17, 2009, Obama signed the <a href="/wiki/American_Recovery_and_Reinvestment_Act_of_2009" title="American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009">American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009</a>, a $787¬†billion <a href="/wiki/Stimulus_(economics)" title="Stimulus (economics)">economic stimulus</a> package aimed at helping the economy recover from the <a href="/wiki/Great_Recession" title="Great Recession">deepening worldwide recession</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-236"><a href="#cite_note-236">[236]</a></sup> The act includes increased federal spending for health care, infrastructure, education, various tax breaks and <a href="/wiki/Tax_incentive" title="Tax incentive">incentives</a>, and direct assistance to individuals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-direct_assistance_237-0"><a href="#cite_note-direct_assistance-237">[237]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:U.S._Total_Deficits_vs._National_Debt_Increases_2001-2010.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="694" data-file-width="914" decoding="async" height="167" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/U.S._Total_Deficits_vs._National_Debt_Increases_2001-2010.png/220px-U.S._Total_Deficits_vs._National_Debt_Increases_2001-2010.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/U.S._Total_Deficits_vs._National_Debt_Increases_2001-2010.png/330px-U.S._Total_Deficits_vs._National_Debt_Increases_2001-2010.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/U.S._Total_Deficits_vs._National_Debt_Increases_2001-2010.png/440px-U.S._Total_Deficits_vs._National_Debt_Increases_2001-2010.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:U.S._Total_Deficits_vs._National_Debt_Increases_2001-2010.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/United_States_federal_budget" title="United States federal budget">Deficit</a> and <a href="/wiki/National_debt_of_the_United_States" title="National debt of the United States">debt</a> increases, 2001‚Äì16</div></div></div>
<p>In March, Obama's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Treasury_Secretary" title="Treasury Secretary">Treasury Secretary</a>, <a href="/wiki/Timothy_Geithner" title="Timothy Geithner">Timothy Geithner</a>, took further steps to manage the <a href="/wiki/Financial_crisis_of_2007%E2%80%9308" title="Financial crisis of 2007‚Äì08">financial crisis</a>, including introducing the <a href="/wiki/Public%E2%80%93Private_Investment_Program_for_Legacy_Assets" title="Public‚ÄìPrivate Investment Program for Legacy Assets">Public‚ÄìPrivate Investment Program for Legacy Assets</a>, which contains provisions for buying up to two¬†trillion dollars in depreciated real estate assets.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-markets_opened_238-0"><a href="#cite_note-markets_opened-238">[238]</a></sup>
</p><p>Obama intervened in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Automotive_industry_crisis_of_2008%E2%80%9310" title="Automotive industry crisis of 2008‚Äì10">troubled automotive industry</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-239"><a href="#cite_note-239">[239]</a></sup> in March 2009, renewing loans for <a href="/wiki/General_Motors" title="General Motors">General Motors</a> and <a href="/wiki/Chrysler" title="Chrysler">Chrysler</a> to continue operations while reorganizing. Over the following months the White House set terms for both firms' bankruptcies, including the <a href="/wiki/Chrysler_Chapter_11_reorganization" title="Chrysler Chapter 11 reorganization">sale of Chrysler</a> to Italian automaker <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fiat" title="Fiat">Fiat</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-240"><a href="#cite_note-240">[240]</a></sup> and a <a href="/wiki/General_Motors_Chapter_11_reorganization" title="General Motors Chapter 11 reorganization">reorganization of GM</a> giving the U.S. government a temporary 60% equity stake in the company, with the Canadian government taking a 12% stake.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-241"><a href="#cite_note-241">[241]</a></sup> In June 2009, dissatisfied with the pace of economic stimulus, Obama called on his cabinet to accelerate the investment.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Christopher_Conkey_and_Louise_Radnofsky_242-0"><a href="#cite_note-Christopher_Conkey_and_Louise_Radnofsky-242">[242]</a></sup> He signed into law the <a href="/wiki/Car_Allowance_Rebate_System" title="Car Allowance Rebate System">Car Allowance Rebate System</a>, known colloquially as "Cash for Clunkers", which temporarily boosted the economy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-243"><a href="#cite_note-243">[243]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-244"><a href="#cite_note-244">[244]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-245"><a href="#cite_note-245">[245]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Bush and Obama administrations authorized spending and loan guarantees from the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Federal_Reserve_System" title="Federal Reserve System">Federal Reserve</a> and the Treasury Department. These guarantees totaled about $11.5¬†trillion, but only $3¬†trillion had been spent by the end of November 2009.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-246"><a href="#cite_note-246">[246]</a></sup> Obama and the <a href="/wiki/Congressional_Budget_Office" title="Congressional Budget Office">Congressional Budget Office</a> predicted the 2010 <a href="/wiki/2010_United_States_federal_budget" title="2010 United States federal budget">budget deficit</a> would be $1.5¬†trillion or 10.6% of the nation's <a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">gross domestic product</a> (GDP) compared to the 2009 deficit of $1.4¬†trillion or 9.9% of GDP.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-247"><a href="#cite_note-247">[247]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-248"><a href="#cite_note-248">[248]</a></sup> For 2011, the administration predicted the deficit would shrink to $1.34¬†trillion, and the 10-year deficit would increase to $8.53¬†trillion or 90% of GDP.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-249"><a href="#cite_note-249">[249]</a></sup> The most recent increase in the U.S. <a href="/wiki/United_States_debt_ceiling" title="United States debt ceiling">debt ceiling</a> to $17.2¬†trillion took effect in February 2014.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-250"><a href="#cite_note-250">[250]</a></sup> On August 2, 2011, after a lengthy congressional debate over whether to raise the nation's debt limit, Obama signed the bipartisan <a href="/wiki/Budget_Control_Act_of_2011" title="Budget Control Act of 2011">Budget Control Act of 2011</a>. The legislation enforces limits on discretionary spending until 2021, establishes a procedure to increase the debt limit, creates a Congressional Joint Select Committee on Deficit Reduction to propose further deficit reduction with a stated goal of achieving at least $1.5¬†trillion in budgetary savings over 10 years, and establishes automatic procedures for reducing spending by as much as $1.2¬†trillion if legislation originating with the new joint select committee does not achieve such savings.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-251"><a href="#cite_note-251">[251]</a></sup> By passing the legislation, Congress was able to prevent a <a href="/wiki/Federal_government_of_the_United_States" title="Federal government of the United States">U.S. government</a> <a href="/wiki/Default_(finance)" title="Default (finance)">default</a> on its obligations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-252"><a href="#cite_note-252">[252]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:US_Employment_Statistics.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="480" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="180" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/US_Employment_Statistics.svg/300px-US_Employment_Statistics.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/US_Employment_Statistics.svg/450px-US_Employment_Statistics.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/US_Employment_Statistics.svg/600px-US_Employment_Statistics.svg.png 2x" width="300"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:US_Employment_Statistics.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>US employment statistics (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Unemployment_rate" title="Unemployment rate">unemployment rate</a> and monthly changes in net employment) during Obama's tenure as U.S. President<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-253"><a href="#cite_note-253">[253]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-254"><a href="#cite_note-254">[254]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>As it did throughout 2008, the unemployment rate rose in 2009, reaching a peak in October at 10.0% and averaging 10.0% in the fourth quarter. Following a decrease to 9.7% in the first quarter of 2010, the unemployment rate fell to 9.6% in the second quarter, where it remained for the rest of the year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Theodossiou_255-0"><a href="#cite_note-Theodossiou-255">[255]</a></sup> Between February and December 2010, employment rose by 0.8%, which was less than the average of 1.9% experienced during comparable periods in the past four employment recoveries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Eddlemon_256-0"><a href="#cite_note-Eddlemon-256">[256]</a></sup> By November 2012, the unemployment rate fell to 7.7%,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-257"><a href="#cite_note-257">[257]</a></sup> decreasing to 6.7% in the last month of 2013.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-258"><a href="#cite_note-258">[258]</a></sup> During 2014, the unemployment rate continued to decline, falling to 6.3% in the first quarter.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-259"><a href="#cite_note-259">[259]</a></sup> GDP growth returned in the third quarter of 2009, expanding at a rate of 1.6%, followed by a 5.0% increase in the fourth quarter.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BEA1_260-0"><a href="#cite_note-BEA1-260">[260]</a></sup> Growth continued in 2010, posting an increase of 3.7% in the first quarter, with lesser gains throughout the rest of the year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BEA1_260-1"><a href="#cite_note-BEA1-260">[260]</a></sup> In July 2010, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Federal_Reserve_System" title="Federal Reserve System">Federal Reserve</a> noted that economic activity continued to increase, but its pace had slowed, and chairman <a href="/wiki/Ben_Bernanke" title="Ben Bernanke">Ben Bernanke</a> said the economic outlook was "unusually uncertain".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-261"><a href="#cite_note-261">[261]</a></sup> Overall, the economy expanded at a rate of 2.9% in 2010.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-262"><a href="#cite_note-262">[262]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Congressional_Budget_Office" title="Congressional Budget Office">Congressional Budget Office</a> (CBO) and a broad range of economists credit Obama's stimulus plan for economic growth.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-estimated_263-0"><a href="#cite_note-estimated-263">[263]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-newc_264-0"><a href="#cite_note-newc-264">[264]</a></sup> The CBO released a report stating that the stimulus bill increased employment by 1‚Äì2.1¬†million,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-newc_264-1"><a href="#cite_note-newc-264">[264]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-265"><a href="#cite_note-265">[265]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-266"><a href="#cite_note-266">[266]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-267"><a href="#cite_note-267">[267]</a></sup> while conceding that "It is impossible to determine how many of the reported jobs would have existed in the absence of the stimulus package."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-estimated_263-1"><a href="#cite_note-estimated-263">[263]</a></sup> Although an April 2010, survey of members of the <a href="/wiki/National_Association_for_Business_Economics" title="National Association for Business Economics">National Association for Business Economics</a> showed an increase in job creation (over a similar January survey) for the first time in two years, 73% of 68 respondents believed the stimulus bill has had no impact on employment.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-268"><a href="#cite_note-268">[268]</a></sup> The economy of the United States has grown faster than the other original <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a> members by a wider margin under President Obama than it has anytime since the end of <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-269"><a href="#cite_note-269">[269]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development</a> credits the much faster growth in the United States to the stimulus plan of the US and the austerity measures in the European Union.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-270"><a href="#cite_note-270">[270]</a></sup>
</p><p>Within a month of the <a href="/wiki/2010_United_States_elections" title="2010 United States elections">2010 midterm elections</a>, Obama announced a compromise deal with the Congressional Republican leadership that included a temporary, two-year extension of the <a href="/wiki/Bush_tax_cuts" title="Bush tax cuts">2001 and 2003 income tax rates</a>, a one-year <a href="/wiki/Federal_Insurance_Contributions_Act_tax" title="Federal Insurance Contributions Act tax">payroll tax</a> reduction, continuation of unemployment benefits, and a new rate and exemption amount for <a href="/wiki/Estate_tax_in_the_United_States" title="Estate tax in the United States">estate taxes</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-271"><a href="#cite_note-271">[271]</a></sup> The compromise overcame opposition from some in both parties, and the resulting $858¬†billion <a href="/wiki/Tax_Relief,_Unemployment_Insurance_Reauthorization,_and_Job_Creation_Act_of_2010" title="Tax Relief, Unemployment Insurance Reauthorization, and Job Creation Act of 2010">Tax Relief, Unemployment Insurance Reauthorization, and Job Creation Act of 2010</a> passed with bipartisan majorities in both houses of Congress before Obama signed it on December 17, 2010.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-272"><a href="#cite_note-272">[272]</a></sup>
</p><p>In December 2013, Obama declared that growing <a href="/wiki/Income_inequality_in_the_United_States" title="Income inequality in the United States">income inequality</a> is a "defining challenge of our time" and called on Congress to bolster the safety net and raise wages. This came on the heels of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fast_food_worker_strikes" title="Fast food worker strikes">nationwide strikes of fast-food workers</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pope_Francis" title="Pope Francis">Pope Francis</a>' criticism of inequality and <a href="/wiki/Trickle-down_economics" title="Trickle-down economics">trickle-down economics</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-273"><a href="#cite_note-273">[273]</a></sup>
</p><p>Obama urged Congress to ratify a 12-nation free trade pact called the <a href="/wiki/Trans-Pacific_Partnership" title="Trans-Pacific Partnership">Trans-Pacific Partnership</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-274"><a href="#cite_note-274">[274]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Environmental_policy">Environmental policy</span></h4>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Climate_change_policy_of_the_United_States" title="Climate change policy of the United States">Climate change policy of the United States</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Obama-venice-la.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2731" data-file-width="4096" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Obama-venice-la.jpg/220px-Obama-venice-la.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Obama-venice-la.jpg/330px-Obama-venice-la.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Obama-venice-la.jpg/440px-Obama-venice-la.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Obama-venice-la.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Obama at a 2010 briefing on the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/BP_oil_spill" title="BP oil spill">BP oil spill</a> at the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Coast_Guard" title="United States Coast Guard">Coast Guard</a> Station Venice in <a href="/wiki/Venice,_Louisiana" title="Venice, Louisiana">Venice, Louisiana</a></div></div></div>
<p>On September 30, 2009, the Obama administration proposed new regulations on power plants, factories, and oil refineries in an attempt to limit greenhouse gas emissions and to curb <a href="/wiki/Global_warming" title="Global warming">global warming</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-275"><a href="#cite_note-275">[275]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-276"><a href="#cite_note-276">[276]</a></sup>
</p><p>On April 20, 2010, an explosion destroyed an offshore <a href="/wiki/Drilling_rig" title="Drilling rig">drilling rig</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Macondo_Prospect" title="Macondo Prospect">Macondo Prospect</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Gulf_of_Mexico" title="Gulf of Mexico">Gulf of Mexico</a>, causing a <a href="/wiki/Deepwater_Horizon_oil_spill" title="Deepwater Horizon oil spill">major sustained oil leak</a>. Obama visited the Gulf, announced a federal investigation, and formed a bipartisan commission to recommend new safety standards, after a review by <a href="/wiki/United_States_Secretary_of_the_Interior" title="United States Secretary of the Interior">Secretary of the Interior</a> <a href="/wiki/Ken_Salazar" title="Ken Salazar">Ken Salazar</a> and concurrent Congressional hearings. He then announced a six-month moratorium on new <a href="/wiki/Deepwater_drilling" title="Deepwater drilling">deepwater drilling</a> permits and leases, pending regulatory review.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-277"><a href="#cite_note-277">[277]</a></sup> As multiple efforts by BP failed, some in the media and public expressed confusion and criticism over various aspects of the incident, and stated a desire for more involvement by Obama and the federal government.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-278"><a href="#cite_note-278">[278]</a></sup>
</p><p>In July 2013, Obama expressed reservations and said he "would reject the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Keystone_XL_pipeline" title="Keystone XL pipeline">Keystone XL pipeline</a> if it increased carbon pollution" or "greenhouse emissions".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-279"><a href="#cite_note-279">[279]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-280"><a href="#cite_note-280">[280]</a></sup> Obama's advisers called for a halt to <a href="/wiki/Petroleum_exploration_in_the_Arctic" title="Petroleum exploration in the Arctic">petroleum exploration in the Arctic</a> in January 2013.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-281"><a href="#cite_note-281">[281]</a></sup> On February 24, 2015, Obama vetoed a bill that would have authorized the pipeline.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-282"><a href="#cite_note-282">[282]</a></sup> It was the third veto of Obama's presidency and his first major veto.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-283"><a href="#cite_note-283">[283]</a></sup>
</p><p>Obama emphasized the <a href="/wiki/Conservation_movement" title="Conservation movement">conservation</a> of <a href="/wiki/Federal_lands" title="Federal lands">federal lands</a> during his term in office. He used his power under the <a href="/wiki/Antiquities_Act" title="Antiquities Act">Antiquities Act</a> to create 25 new <a href="/wiki/National_monument_(United_States)" title="National monument (United States)">national monuments</a> during his presidency and expand four others, protecting a total of 553,000,000 acres (224,000,000¬†ha) of federal lands and waters, more than any other U.S. president.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Monuments_284-0"><a href="#cite_note-Monuments-284">[284]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Health_care_reform">Health care reform</span></h4>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Health_care_reform_in_the_United_States" title="Health care reform in the United States">Health care reform in the United States</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Obama_signs_health_care-20100323.jpg"><img alt="Photograph" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="683" data-file-width="1024" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Obama_signs_health_care-20100323.jpg/220px-Obama_signs_health_care-20100323.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Obama_signs_health_care-20100323.jpg/330px-Obama_signs_health_care-20100323.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Obama_signs_health_care-20100323.jpg/440px-Obama_signs_health_care-20100323.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Obama_signs_health_care-20100323.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Obama signs the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act at the White House, March 23, 2010.</div></div></div>
<p>Obama called for <a href="/wiki/United_States_Congress" title="United States Congress">Congress</a> to pass legislation reforming <a href="/wiki/Health_care_in_the_United_States" title="Health care in the United States">health care in the United States</a>, a key campaign promise and a top legislative goal.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-health_reform_285-0"><a href="#cite_note-health_reform-285">[285]</a></sup> He proposed an expansion of health insurance coverage to cover the uninsured, to cap premium increases, and to allow people to retain their coverage when they leave or change jobs. His proposal was to spend $900¬†billion over 10 years and include a government insurance plan, also known as the <a href="/wiki/Public_health_insurance_option" title="Public health insurance option">public option</a>, to compete with the corporate insurance sector as a main component to lowering costs and improving quality of health care. It would also make it illegal for insurers to drop sick people or deny them coverage for <a href="/wiki/Pre-existing_condition" title="Pre-existing condition">pre-existing conditions</a>, and require every American to carry health coverage. The plan also includes medical spending cuts and taxes on insurance companies that offer expensive plans.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-286"><a href="#cite_note-286">[286]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-287"><a href="#cite_note-287">[287]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:PPACA_Premium_Chart.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="513" data-file-width="663" decoding="async" height="232" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/PPACA_Premium_Chart.jpg/300px-PPACA_Premium_Chart.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/PPACA_Premium_Chart.jpg/450px-PPACA_Premium_Chart.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/PPACA_Premium_Chart.jpg/600px-PPACA_Premium_Chart.jpg 2x" width="300"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:PPACA_Premium_Chart.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Maximum Out-of-Pocket Premium as Percentage of Family Income and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Federal_poverty_level" title="Federal poverty level">federal poverty level</a>, under <a href="/wiki/Patient_Protection_and_Affordable_Care_Act" title="Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act">Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act</a>, starting in 2014 (Source: <a href="/wiki/Congressional_Research_Service" title="Congressional Research Service">CRS</a>)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-288"><a href="#cite_note-288">[288]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>On July 14, 2009, House Democratic leaders introduced a 1,017-page plan for overhauling the U.S. health care system, which Obama wanted Congress to approve by the end of 2009.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-health_reform_285-1"><a href="#cite_note-health_reform-285">[285]</a></sup> After much public debate during the Congressional summer recess of 2009, Obama delivered <a href="/wiki/Barack_Obama_speech_to_joint_session_of_Congress,_September_2009" title="Barack Obama speech to joint session of Congress, September 2009">a speech to a joint session of Congress</a> on September<span class="nowrap">¬†</span>9 where he addressed concerns over the proposals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-289"><a href="#cite_note-289">[289]</a></sup> In March 2009, Obama lifted a ban on using federal funds for stem cell research.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-290"><a href="#cite_note-290">[290]</a></sup>
</p><p>On November 7, 2009, a health care bill featuring the public option was passed in the House.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nyt1_291-0"><a href="#cite_note-nyt1-291">[291]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nyt_292-0"><a href="#cite_note-nyt-292">[292]</a></sup> On December 24, 2009, the Senate passed its own bill‚Äîwithout a public option‚Äîon a party-line vote of 60‚Äì39.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-293"><a href="#cite_note-293">[293]</a></sup> On March 21, 2010, the <a href="/wiki/Patient_Protection_and_Affordable_Care_Act" title="Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act">Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act</a> (ACA) passed by the Senate in December was passed in the House by a vote of 219 to 212.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-294"><a href="#cite_note-294">[294]</a></sup> Obama signed the bill into law on March 23, 2010.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-295"><a href="#cite_note-295">[295]</a></sup>
</p><p>The ACA includes <a href="/wiki/Provisions_of_the_Patient_Protection_and_Affordable_Care_Act" title="Provisions of the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act">health-related provisions</a>, most of which took effect in 2014, including expanding <a href="/wiki/Medicaid" title="Medicaid">Medicaid</a> eligibility for people making up to 133%¬†of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Federal_poverty_level" title="Federal poverty level">federal poverty level</a> (FPL) starting in 2014,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cnn_ref1_296-0"><a href="#cite_note-cnn_ref1-296">[296]</a></sup> subsidizing insurance premiums for people making up to 400%¬†of the FPL ($88,000 for family of four in 2010) so their maximum "out-of-pocket" payment for annual premiums will be from 2% to 9.5% of income,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-whitehouse_297-0"><a href="#cite_note-whitehouse-297">[297]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-298"><a href="#cite_note-298">[298]</a></sup> providing incentives for businesses to provide health care benefits, prohibiting denial of coverage and denial of claims based on pre-existing conditions, establishing <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Health_insurance_exchange" title="Health insurance exchange">health insurance exchanges</a>, prohibiting annual coverage caps, and support for medical research. According to White House and CBO figures, the maximum share of income that enrollees would have to pay would vary depending on their income relative to the federal poverty level.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-whitehouse_297-1"><a href="#cite_note-whitehouse-297">[297]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cbo_est_299-0"><a href="#cite_note-cbo_est-299">[299]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Percentage_of_Individuals_in_the_United_States_Without_Health_Insurance,_1963-2015.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="693" data-file-width="949" decoding="async" height="161" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Percentage_of_Individuals_in_the_United_States_Without_Health_Insurance%2C_1963-2015.png/220px-Percentage_of_Individuals_in_the_United_States_Without_Health_Insurance%2C_1963-2015.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Percentage_of_Individuals_in_the_United_States_Without_Health_Insurance%2C_1963-2015.png/330px-Percentage_of_Individuals_in_the_United_States_Without_Health_Insurance%2C_1963-2015.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Percentage_of_Individuals_in_the_United_States_Without_Health_Insurance%2C_1963-2015.png/440px-Percentage_of_Individuals_in_the_United_States_Without_Health_Insurance%2C_1963-2015.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Percentage_of_Individuals_in_the_United_States_Without_Health_Insurance,_1963-2015.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Percentage of Individuals in the United States without Health Insurance, 1963‚Äì2015 (Source: <a href="/wiki/JAMA_(journal)" title="JAMA (journal)">JAMA</a>)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-300"><a href="#cite_note-300">[300]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>The costs of these provisions are offset by taxes, fees, and cost-saving measures, such as new Medicare taxes for those in high-income <a href="/wiki/Tax_bracket" title="Tax bracket">brackets</a>, taxes on <a href="/wiki/Indoor_tanning" title="Indoor tanning">indoor tanning</a>, cuts to the <a href="/wiki/Medicare_Advantage" title="Medicare Advantage">Medicare Advantage</a> program in favor of traditional Medicare, and fees on medical devices and pharmaceutical companies;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-301"><a href="#cite_note-301">[301]</a></sup> there is also a tax penalty for those who do not obtain health insurance, unless they are exempt due to low income or other reasons.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-302"><a href="#cite_note-302">[302]</a></sup> In March 2010, the CBO estimated that the net effect of both laws will be a reduction in the federal deficit by $143¬†billion over the first decade.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-303"><a href="#cite_note-303">[303]</a></sup>
</p><p>The law faced several legal challenges, primarily based on the argument that an individual mandate requiring Americans to buy health insurance was unconstitutional. On June 28, 2012, the Supreme Court ruled by a 5‚Äì4 vote in <i><a href="/wiki/National_Federation_of_Independent_Business_v._Sebelius" title="National Federation of Independent Business v. Sebelius">National Federation of Independent Business v. Sebelius</a></i> that the mandate was constitutional under the U.S. Congress's taxing authority.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WP-uphold_304-0"><a href="#cite_note-WP-uphold-304">[304]</a></sup> In <i><a href="/wiki/Burwell_v._Hobby_Lobby_Stores,_Inc." title="Burwell v. Hobby Lobby Stores, Inc.">Burwell v. Hobby Lobby</a></i> the Court ruled that "closely-held" for-profit corporations could be exempt on religious grounds under the <a href="/wiki/Religious_Freedom_Restoration_Act" title="Religious Freedom Restoration Act">Religious Freedom Restoration Act</a> from regulations adopted under the ACA that would have required them to pay for insurance that covered certain contraceptives. In June 2015, the Court ruled 6‚Äì3 in <i><a href="/wiki/King_v._Burwell" title="King v. Burwell">King v. Burwell</a></i> that subsidies to help individuals and families purchase health insurance were authorized for those doing so on both the federal exchange and state exchanges, not only those purchasing plans "established by the State", as the statute reads.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-305"><a href="#cite_note-305">[305]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Energy_policy">Energy policy</span></h4>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Energy_policy_of_the_Obama_administration" title="Energy policy of the Obama administration">Energy policy of the Obama administration</a></div>
<p>Prior to June 2014, Obama offered substantial support for a broadly-based "All of the above" approach to domestic <a href="/wiki/Energy_policy" title="Energy policy">energy policy</a>, which Obama has maintained since his first term and which he last confirmed at his <a href="/wiki/State_of_the_Union" title="State of the Union">State of the Union</a> speech in January 2014 to a mixed reception by both parties. In June 2014, Obama made indications that his administration would consider a shift towards an energy policy more closely tuned to the manufacturing industry and its impact on the domestic economy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-306"><a href="#cite_note-306">[306]</a></sup> Obama's approach of selectively combining regulation and incentive to various issues in the domestic energy policy, such as coal mining and oil fracking, has received mixed commentary for not being as responsive to the needs of the domestic manufacturing sector as needed, following claims that the domestic manufacturing sector utilizes as much as a third of the nation's available energy resources.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-307"><a href="#cite_note-307">[307]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-308"><a href="#cite_note-308">[308]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Gun_control">Gun control</span></h4>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Social_policy_of_the_Barack_Obama_administration#Gun_policy" title="Social policy of the Barack Obama administration">Social policy of the Barack Obama administration ¬ß¬†Gun policy</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Barack_Obama_visiting_victims_of_2012_Aurora_shooting.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2620" data-file-width="3908" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Barack_Obama_visiting_victims_of_2012_Aurora_shooting.jpg/220px-Barack_Obama_visiting_victims_of_2012_Aurora_shooting.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Barack_Obama_visiting_victims_of_2012_Aurora_shooting.jpg/330px-Barack_Obama_visiting_victims_of_2012_Aurora_shooting.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Barack_Obama_visiting_victims_of_2012_Aurora_shooting.jpg/440px-Barack_Obama_visiting_victims_of_2012_Aurora_shooting.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Barack_Obama_visiting_victims_of_2012_Aurora_shooting.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Obama visits an <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2012_Aurora_shooting" title="2012 Aurora shooting">Aurora shooting</a> victim at <a href="/wiki/University_of_Colorado_Hospital" title="University of Colorado Hospital">University of Colorado Hospital</a>, 2012.</div></div></div>
<p>On January 16, 2013, one month after the <a href="/wiki/Sandy_Hook_Elementary_School_shooting" title="Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting">Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting</a>, Obama signed 23 executive orders and outlined a series of sweeping proposals regarding <a href="/wiki/Gun_politics_in_the_United_States" title="Gun politics in the United States">gun control</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-309"><a href="#cite_note-309">[309]</a></sup> He urged Congress to reintroduce an <a href="/wiki/Federal_Assault_Weapons_Ban" title="Federal Assault Weapons Ban">expired ban</a> on military-style <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Assault_weapons" title="Assault weapons">assault weapons</a>, such as those used in several recent mass shootings, impose limits on ammunition magazines to 10 rounds, introduce background checks on all gun sales, pass a ban on possession and sale of armor-piercing bullets, introduce harsher penalties for gun-traffickers, especially unlicensed dealers who buy arms for criminals and approving the appointment of the head of the federal <a href="/wiki/Bureau_of_Alcohol,_Tobacco,_Firearms_and_Explosives" title="Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives">Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives</a> for the first time since 2006.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-310"><a href="#cite_note-310">[310]</a></sup> On January 5, 2016, Obama announced new executive actions extending background check requirements to more gun sellers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-311"><a href="#cite_note-311">[311]</a></sup> In a 2016 editorial in the <i>New York Times</i>, Obama compared the struggle for what he termed "common-sense gun reform" to <a href="/wiki/Women%27s_suffrage" title="Women's suffrage">women's suffrage</a> and other <a href="/wiki/Civil_rights_movements" title="Civil rights movements">civil rights movements</a> in American history.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-312"><a href="#cite_note-312">[312]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="2010_midterm_elections">2010 midterm elections</span></h4>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/2010_United_States_House_of_Representatives_elections" title="2010 United States House of Representatives elections">2010 United States House of Representatives elections</a> and <a href="/wiki/2010_United_States_Senate_elections" title="2010 United States Senate elections">2010 United States Senate elections</a></div>
<p>Obama called the <a href="/wiki/2010_United_States_House_of_Representatives_elections" title="2010 United States House of Representatives elections">November 2, 2010 election</a>, where the Democratic Party lost 63 seats in, and control of, the House of Representatives,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-313"><a href="#cite_note-313">[313]</a></sup> "humbling" and a "shellacking".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-314"><a href="#cite_note-314">[314]</a></sup> He said that the results came because not enough Americans had felt the effects of the economic recovery.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-315"><a href="#cite_note-315">[315]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Cybersecurity_and_Internet_policy">Cybersecurity and Internet policy</span></h4>
<p>On November 10, 2014, President Obama recommended the <a href="/wiki/Federal_Communications_Commission" title="Federal Communications Commission">Federal Communications Commission</a> reclassify <a href="/wiki/Internet_access" title="Internet access">broadband Internet service</a> as a telecommunications service in order to preserve <a href="/wiki/Net_neutrality" title="Net neutrality">net neutrality</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT-20141110-EW_316-0"><a href="#cite_note-NYT-20141110-EW-316">[316]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT-20141114_317-0"><a href="#cite_note-NYT-20141114-317">[317]</a></sup> On February 12, 2013, President Obama signed <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Executive_order_(United_States)" title="Executive order (United States)">Executive Order</a> <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Executive_Order_13636" title="s:Executive Order 13636">13636</a>, "Improving Critical Infrastructure Cybersecurity."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-318"><a href="#cite_note-318">[318]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Government_mass_surveillance">Government mass surveillance</span></h4>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Barack_Obama_on_mass_surveillance" title="Barack Obama on mass surveillance">Barack Obama on mass surveillance</a></div>
<p>In 2005 and 2006, Obama criticized certain aspects of the <a href="/wiki/Patriot_Act" title="Patriot Act">Patriot Act</a> for infringing too much on civil liberties and sought as Senator to strengthen civil liberties protections.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-319"><a href="#cite_note-319">[319]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CNN-Snowden_320-0"><a href="#cite_note-CNN-Snowden-320">[320]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_321-0"><a href="#cite_note-:0-321">[321]</a></sup> In 2006, he voted to reauthorize a revised version of the Patriot Act, saying the law was not ideal but that the revised version had strengthened civil liberties.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_321-1"><a href="#cite_note-:0-321">[321]</a></sup> In 2011, he signed a four-year renewal of the Patriot Act.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-322"><a href="#cite_note-322">[322]</a></sup> Following the <a href="/wiki/Global_surveillance_disclosures_(2013%E2%80%93present)" title="Global surveillance disclosures (2013‚Äìpresent)">2013 global surveillance disclosures</a> by <a href="/wiki/Whistleblower" title="Whistleblower">whistleblower</a> <a href="/wiki/Edward_Snowden" title="Edward Snowden">Edward Snowden</a>, Obama condemned the leak as unpatriotic,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CNN-Snowden_320-1"><a href="#cite_note-CNN-Snowden-320">[320]</a></sup> but called for increased restrictions on the NSA to address violations of privacy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-323"><a href="#cite_note-323">[323]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-324"><a href="#cite_note-324">[324]</a></sup> The changes which Obama ordered have been described as "modest" however.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-325"><a href="#cite_note-325">[325]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_policy">Foreign policy</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_policy_of_the_Barack_Obama_administration" title="Foreign policy of the Barack Obama administration">Foreign policy of the Barack Obama administration</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:P06409PS-0571_(3594694537).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2334" data-file-width="3500" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/P06409PS-0571_%283594694537%29.jpg/220px-P06409PS-0571_%283594694537%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/P06409PS-0571_%283594694537%29.jpg/330px-P06409PS-0571_%283594694537%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/P06409PS-0571_%283594694537%29.jpg/440px-P06409PS-0571_%283594694537%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:P06409PS-0571_(3594694537).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>June 4, 2009 ‚àí after his speech <i><a href="/wiki/A_New_Beginning" title="A New Beginning">A New Beginning</a></i> at <a href="/wiki/Cairo_University" title="Cairo University">Cairo University</a>, U.S. President Obama participates in a roundtable interview in 2009 with among others <a href="/wiki/Jamal_Khashoggi" title="Jamal Khashoggi">Jamal Khashoggi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bambang_Harymurti" title="Bambang Harymurti">Bambang Harymurti</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nahum_Barnea" title="Nahum Barnea">Nahum Barnea</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>In February and March 2009, Vice President Joe Biden and <a href="/wiki/United_States_Secretary_of_State" title="United States Secretary of State">Secretary of State</a> Hillary Clinton made separate overseas trips to announce a "new era" in U.S. foreign relations with Russia and Europe, using the terms "break" and "<a href="/wiki/Russian_reset" title="Russian reset">reset</a>" to signal major changes from the policies of the preceding administration.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-preceding_administration_326-0"><a href="#cite_note-preceding_administration-326">[326]</a></sup> Obama attempted to reach out to Arab leaders by granting his first interview to an Arab satellite TV network, <a href="/wiki/Al_Arabiya" title="Al Arabiya">Al Arabiya</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-327"><a href="#cite_note-327">[327]</a></sup>
</p><p>On March 19, Obama continued his outreach to the Muslim world, releasing a New Year's video message to the people and government of Iran.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-328"><a href="#cite_note-328">[328]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-329"><a href="#cite_note-329">[329]</a></sup> In April, Obama gave a speech in <a href="/wiki/Ankara" title="Ankara">Ankara</a>, Turkey, which was well received by many Arab governments.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-330"><a href="#cite_note-330">[330]</a></sup> On June 4, 2009, Obama delivered a speech at <a href="/wiki/Cairo_University" title="Cairo University">Cairo University</a> in Egypt calling for "<a href="/wiki/A_New_Beginning" title="A New Beginning">A New Beginning</a>" in relations between the Islamic world and the United States and promoting Middle East peace.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-middleeast_331-0"><a href="#cite_note-middleeast-331">[331]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Barack_Obama_foreign_trips.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1398" data-file-width="2754" decoding="async" height="112" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Barack_Obama_foreign_trips.svg/220px-Barack_Obama_foreign_trips.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Barack_Obama_foreign_trips.svg/330px-Barack_Obama_foreign_trips.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Barack_Obama_foreign_trips.svg/440px-Barack_Obama_foreign_trips.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Barack_Obama_foreign_trips.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/List_of_international_presidential_trips_made_by_Barack_Obama" title="List of international presidential trips made by Barack Obama">International trips</a> made by President Barack Obama during his terms in office</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Merkel_an_Obama_Presidential_Medal_of_Freedom.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="436" data-file-width="648" decoding="async" height="148" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Merkel_an_Obama_Presidential_Medal_of_Freedom.jpg/220px-Merkel_an_Obama_Presidential_Medal_of_Freedom.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Merkel_an_Obama_Presidential_Medal_of_Freedom.jpg/330px-Merkel_an_Obama_Presidential_Medal_of_Freedom.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Merkel_an_Obama_Presidential_Medal_of_Freedom.jpg/440px-Merkel_an_Obama_Presidential_Medal_of_Freedom.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Merkel_an_Obama_Presidential_Medal_of_Freedom.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Obama with German Chancellor <a href="/wiki/Angela_Merkel" title="Angela Merkel">Angela Merkel</a> in 2011</div></div></div>
<p>On June 26, 2009, Obama responded to the Iranian government's actions towards protesters following <a href="/wiki/2009_Iranian_presidential_election" title="2009 Iranian presidential election">Iran's 2009 presidential election</a> by saying: "The violence perpetrated against them is outrageous. We see it and we condemn it."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-332"><a href="#cite_note-332">[332]</a></sup> While in Moscow on July 7, he responded to Vice President Biden's comment on a possible Israeli military strike on Iran by saying: "We have said directly to the Israelis that it is important to try and resolve this in an international setting in a way that does not create major conflict in the Middle East."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-333"><a href="#cite_note-333">[333]</a></sup>
</p><p>On September 24, 2009, Obama became the first sitting U.S. President to <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_United_Nations_Security_Council" title="President of the United Nations Security Council">preside</a> over a meeting of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council" title="United Nations Security Council">United Nations Security Council</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-334"><a href="#cite_note-334">[334]</a></sup>
</p><p>In March 2010, Obama took a public stance against plans by the government of Israeli Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Benjamin_Netanyahu" title="Benjamin Netanyahu">Benjamin Netanyahu</a> to continue building Jewish housing projects in predominantly Arab neighborhoods of <a href="/wiki/East_Jerusalem" title="East Jerusalem">East Jerusalem</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-335"><a href="#cite_note-335">[335]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-336"><a href="#cite_note-336">[336]</a></sup> During the same month, an agreement was reached with the administration of Russian President <a href="/wiki/Dmitry_Medvedev" title="Dmitry Medvedev">Dmitry Medvedev</a> to replace the <a href="/wiki/START_I" title="START I">1991 Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty</a> with a new pact reducing the number of long-range nuclear weapons in the arsenals of both countries by about a third.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-337"><a href="#cite_note-337">[337]</a></sup> Obama and Medvedev signed the <a href="/wiki/New_START" title="New START">New START</a> treaty in April 2010, and the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Senate" title="United States Senate">U.S. Senate</a> ratified it in December 2010.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-338"><a href="#cite_note-338">[338]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Barack_Obama_and_Matteo_Renzi_October_2016,_1.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1003" data-file-width="1256" decoding="async" height="176" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Barack_Obama_and_Matteo_Renzi_October_2016%2C_1.jpg/220px-Barack_Obama_and_Matteo_Renzi_October_2016%2C_1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Barack_Obama_and_Matteo_Renzi_October_2016%2C_1.jpg/330px-Barack_Obama_and_Matteo_Renzi_October_2016%2C_1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Barack_Obama_and_Matteo_Renzi_October_2016%2C_1.jpg/440px-Barack_Obama_and_Matteo_Renzi_October_2016%2C_1.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Barack_Obama_and_Matteo_Renzi_October_2016,_1.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Obama meets with Italian Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Matteo_Renzi" title="Matteo Renzi">Matteo Renzi</a> at the <a href="/wiki/White_House" title="White House">White House</a>, October 2016.</div></div></div>
<p>In December 2011, Obama instructed agencies to consider <a href="/wiki/LGBT_rights_by_country_or_territory" title="LGBT rights by country or territory">LGBT rights</a> when issuing financial aid to foreign countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-339"><a href="#cite_note-339">[339]</a></sup> In August 2013, he criticized Russia's law that discriminates against gays,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LAT80713_340-0"><a href="#cite_note-LAT80713-340">[340]</a></sup> but he stopped short of advocating a boycott of the upcoming <a href="/wiki/2014_Winter_Olympics" title="2014 Winter Olympics">2014 Winter Olympics</a> in <a href="/wiki/Sochi" title="Sochi">Sochi</a>, Russia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Huffpo80913_341-0"><a href="#cite_note-Huffpo80913-341">[341]</a></sup>
</p><p>In December 2014, Obama announced that he intended to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_States%E2%80%93Cuban_Thaw" title="United States‚ÄìCuban Thaw">normalize relationships</a> between <a href="/wiki/Cuba%E2%80%93United_States_relations" title="Cuba‚ÄìUnited States relations">Cuba and the United States</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-342"><a href="#cite_note-342">[342]</a></sup> The countries' respective "interests sections" in one another's capitals were upgraded to embassies on July 20, 2015.
</p><p>In March 2015, Obama declared that he had authorized U.S. forces to provide logistical and intelligence support to the Saudis in their <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabian-led_intervention_in_Yemen" title="Saudi Arabian-led intervention in Yemen">military intervention in Yemen</a>, establishing a "Joint Planning Cell" with Saudi Arabia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-343"><a href="#cite_note-343">[343]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-344"><a href="#cite_note-344">[344]</a></sup> In 2016, the Obama administration proposed a series of <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabia%E2%80%93United_States_relations" title="Saudi Arabia‚ÄìUnited States relations">arms deals with Saudi Arabia</a> worth $115 billion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-345"><a href="#cite_note-345">[345]</a></sup> Obama halted the sale of guided munition technology to <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabia" title="Saudi Arabia">Saudi Arabia</a> after Saudi warplanes <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2016_Sana%27a_funeral_airstrike" title="2016 Sana'a funeral airstrike">targeted a funeral</a> in Yemen's capital Sanaa, killing more than 140 people.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-346"><a href="#cite_note-346">[346]</a></sup>
</p><p>Before leaving office, Obama said German Chancellor <a href="/wiki/Angela_Merkel" title="Angela Merkel">Angela Merkel</a> had been his "closest international partner" throughout his tenure as president.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-thelocal2016_347-0"><a href="#cite_note-thelocal2016-347">[347]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="War_in_Iraq">War in Iraq</span></h4>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Iraq_War" title="Iraq War">Iraq War</a> and <a href="/wiki/American-led_intervention_in_Iraq_(2014%E2%80%93present)" title="American-led intervention in Iraq (2014‚Äìpresent)">American-led intervention in Iraq (2014‚Äìpresent)</a></div>
<p>On February 27, 2009, Obama announced that combat operations in Iraq would end within 18 months. His remarks were made to a group of <a href="/wiki/United_States_Marine_Corps" title="United States Marine Corps">Marines</a> preparing for deployment to Afghanistan. Obama said, "Let me say this as plainly as I can: by August 31, 2010, our combat mission in Iraq will end."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-348"><a href="#cite_note-348">[348]</a></sup> The Obama administration scheduled the withdrawal of combat troops to be completed by August 2010, decreasing troop's levels from 142,000 while leaving a transitional force of about 50,000 in Iraq until the end of 2011. On August 19, 2010, the last U.S. combat brigade exited Iraq. Remaining troops transitioned from combat operations to <a href="/wiki/Counter-terrorism" title="Counter-terrorism">counter-terrorism</a> and the training, equipping, and advising of Iraqi security forces.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-349"><a href="#cite_note-349">[349]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-350"><a href="#cite_note-350">[350]</a></sup> On August 31, 2010, Obama announced that the United States combat mission in Iraq was over.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-351"><a href="#cite_note-351">[351]</a></sup> On October 21, 2011 President Obama announced that all U.S. troops would leave Iraq in time to be "home for the holidays".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-352"><a href="#cite_note-352">[352]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:David_Cameron_and_Barack_Obama_at_the_G20_Summit_in_Toronto.jpg"><img alt="US President Barack Obama and British Prime Minister David Cameron trade bottles of beer to settle a bet they made on the U.S. vs. England World Cup Soccer game (which ended in a tie), during a bilateral meeting at the G20 Summit in Toronto, Canada, Saturday, June 26, 2010." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2731" data-file-width="4096" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/be/David_Cameron_and_Barack_Obama_at_the_G20_Summit_in_Toronto.jpg/220px-David_Cameron_and_Barack_Obama_at_the_G20_Summit_in_Toronto.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/be/David_Cameron_and_Barack_Obama_at_the_G20_Summit_in_Toronto.jpg/330px-David_Cameron_and_Barack_Obama_at_the_G20_Summit_in_Toronto.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/be/David_Cameron_and_Barack_Obama_at_the_G20_Summit_in_Toronto.jpg/440px-David_Cameron_and_Barack_Obama_at_the_G20_Summit_in_Toronto.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:David_Cameron_and_Barack_Obama_at_the_G20_Summit_in_Toronto.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Meeting with UK Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/David_Cameron" title="David Cameron">David Cameron</a> during the <a href="/wiki/2010_G20_Toronto_summit" title="2010 G20 Toronto summit">2010 G20 Toronto summit</a></div></div></div>
<p>In June 2014, following the <a href="/wiki/Northern_Iraq_offensive_(June_2014)#Fall_of_Mosul_and_push_into_Kirkuk" title="Northern Iraq offensive (June 2014)">capture of Mosul</a> by <a href="/wiki/Islamic_State_of_Iraq_and_the_Levant" title="Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant">ISIS</a>, Obama sent 275 troops to provide support and security for U.S. personnel and the U.S. Embassy in Baghdad. ISIS continued to gain ground and to commit <a href="/wiki/Islamic_State_of_Iraq_and_the_Levant#Human_rights_abuse_and_war_crime_findings" title="Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant">widespread massacres and ethnic cleansing</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-353"><a href="#cite_note-353">[353]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-354"><a href="#cite_note-354">[354]</a></sup>
</p><p>In August 2014, during the <a href="/wiki/Sinjar_massacre" title="Sinjar massacre">Sinjar massacre</a>, Obama ordered a <a href="/wiki/American-led_intervention_in_Iraq_(2014%E2%80%93present)#United_States_airstrikes" title="American-led intervention in Iraq (2014‚Äìpresent)">campaign of U.S. airstrikes against ISIS</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-def31-10-14_355-0"><a href="#cite_note-def31-10-14-355">[355]</a></sup>
</p><p>By the end of 2014, 3,100 American ground troops were committed to the conflict<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-356"><a href="#cite_note-356">[356]</a></sup> and 16,000 sorties were flown over the battlefield, primarily by U.S. Air Force and Navy pilots.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-357"><a href="#cite_note-357">[357]</a></sup>
</p><p>In early 2015, with the addition of the "Panther Brigade" of the <a href="/wiki/82nd_Airborne_Division" title="82nd Airborne Division">82nd Airborne Division</a> the number of U.S. ground troops in Iraq surged to 4,400,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-358"><a href="#cite_note-358">[358]</a></sup> and by July American-led coalition air forces counted 44,000 sorties over the battlefield.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-359"><a href="#cite_note-359">[359]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="War_in_Afghanistan">War in Afghanistan</span></h4>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/War_in_Afghanistan_(2001%E2%80%93present)" title="War in Afghanistan (2001‚Äìpresent)">War in Afghanistan (2001‚Äìpresent)</a></div>
<p>Early in his presidency, Obama moved to bolster U.S. troop strength in Afghanistan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_360-0"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-360">[360]</a></sup> He announced an increase in U.S. troop levels to 17,000 military personnel in February 2009 to "stabilize a deteriorating situation in Afghanistan", an area he said had not received the "strategic attention, direction and resources it urgently requires".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-361"><a href="#cite_note-361">[361]</a></sup> He replaced the military commander in Afghanistan, General <a href="/wiki/David_D._McKiernan" title="David D. McKiernan">David D. McKiernan</a>, with former <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Special_Forces_(United_States_Army)" title="Special Forces (United States Army)">Special Forces</a> commander Lt. Gen. <a href="/wiki/Stanley_A._McChrystal" title="Stanley A. McChrystal">Stanley A. McChrystal</a> in May 2009, indicating that McChrystal's Special Forces experience would facilitate the use of counterinsurgency tactics in the war.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-counterinsurgency_tactics_362-0"><a href="#cite_note-counterinsurgency_tactics-362">[362]</a></sup> On December 1, 2009, Obama announced the deployment of an additional 30,000 military personnel to Afghanistan and proposed to begin troop withdrawals 18 months from that date;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-363"><a href="#cite_note-363">[363]</a></sup> this took place in July 2011. <a href="/wiki/David_Petraeus" title="David Petraeus">David Petraeus</a> replaced McChrystal in June 2010, after McChrystal's staff criticized White House personnel in a magazine article.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-364"><a href="#cite_note-364">[364]</a></sup> In February 2013, Obama said the U.S. military would reduce the troop level in Afghanistan from 68,000 to 34,000 U.S. troops by February 2014.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-365"><a href="#cite_note-365">[365]</a></sup>
</p><p>In October 2015, the White House announced a plan to keep U.S. Forces in Afghanistan indefinitely in light of the deteriorating security situation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-366"><a href="#cite_note-366">[366]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Israel">Israel</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Barack_Obama_welcomes_Shimon_Peres_in_the_Oval_Office.jpg"><img alt="President Barack Obama, at left, shakes hands with Israeli President Shimon Peres, at right, in the Oval Office on Tuesday, May 5, 2009. Standing at right looking on is U.S. Vice President Joe Biden." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2333" data-file-width="3500" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Barack_Obama_welcomes_Shimon_Peres_in_the_Oval_Office.jpg/220px-Barack_Obama_welcomes_Shimon_Peres_in_the_Oval_Office.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Barack_Obama_welcomes_Shimon_Peres_in_the_Oval_Office.jpg/330px-Barack_Obama_welcomes_Shimon_Peres_in_the_Oval_Office.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Barack_Obama_welcomes_Shimon_Peres_in_the_Oval_Office.jpg/440px-Barack_Obama_welcomes_Shimon_Peres_in_the_Oval_Office.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Barack_Obama_welcomes_Shimon_Peres_in_the_Oval_Office.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Obama meeting with Israeli President <a href="/wiki/Shimon_Peres" title="Shimon Peres">Shimon Peres</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Oval_Office" title="Oval Office">Oval Office</a>, May 2009</div></div></div>
<p>In 2011, the United States vetoed a Security Council resolution condemning <a href="/wiki/Israeli_settlement" title="Israeli settlement">Israeli settlements</a>, with the United States being the only nation to do so.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-367"><a href="#cite_note-367">[367]</a></sup> Obama supports the <a href="/wiki/Two-state_solution" title="Two-state solution">two-state solution</a> to the <a href="/wiki/Arab%E2%80%93Israeli_conflict" title="Arab‚ÄìIsraeli conflict">Arab‚ÄìIsraeli conflict</a> based on the 1967 borders with land swaps.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-368"><a href="#cite_note-368">[368]</a></sup>
</p><p>In June 2011, Obama said the bond between the United States and Israel is "unbreakable".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-369"><a href="#cite_note-369">[369]</a></sup> During the initial years of the Obama administration, the U.S. increased military cooperation with Israel, including increased military aid, re-establishment of the <a href="/wiki/Joint_Political_Military_Group" title="Joint Political Military Group">U.S.-Israeli Joint Political Military Group</a> and the Defense Policy Advisory Group, and an increase in visits among high-level military officials of both countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-370"><a href="#cite_note-370">[370]</a></sup> The Obama administration asked Congress to allocate money toward funding the <a href="/wiki/Iron_Dome" title="Iron Dome">Iron Dome</a> program in response to the waves of <a href="/wiki/Palestinian_rocket_attacks_on_Israel" title="Palestinian rocket attacks on Israel">Palestinian rocket attacks on Israel</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-371"><a href="#cite_note-371">[371]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2013, <a href="/wiki/Jeffrey_Goldberg" title="Jeffrey Goldberg">Jeffrey Goldberg</a> reported that, in Obama's view, "with each new settlement announcement, Netanyahu is moving his country down a path toward near-total isolation."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bloomberg_372-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bloomberg-372">[372]</a></sup> In 2014, Obama likened the <a href="/wiki/Zionism" title="Zionism">Zionist movement</a> to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Civil_Rights_Movement" title="Civil Rights Movement">Civil Rights Movement</a> in the United States. He said both movements seek to bring justice and equal rights to historically persecuted peoples. He explained, "To me, being pro-Israel and pro-Jewish is part and parcel with the values that I've been fighting for since I was politically conscious and started getting involved in politics."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-373"><a href="#cite_note-373">[373]</a></sup> Obama expressed support for Israel's right to defend itself during the <a href="/wiki/2014_Israel%E2%80%93Gaza_conflict" title="2014 Israel‚ÄìGaza conflict">2014 Israel‚ÄìGaza conflict</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-374"><a href="#cite_note-374">[374]</a></sup> In 2015, Obama was harshly criticized by Israel for advocating and signing the <a href="/wiki/Joint_Comprehensive_Plan_of_Action" title="Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action">Iran Nuclear Deal</a>; Israeli Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Benjamin_Netanyahu" title="Benjamin Netanyahu">Benjamin Netanyahu</a>, who had advocated the U.S. congress to oppose it, said the deal was "dangerous" and "bad".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-375"><a href="#cite_note-375">[375]</a></sup>
</p><p>On December 23, 2016, under the Obama Administration, the United States abstained from <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council_Resolution_2334" title="United Nations Security Council Resolution 2334">United Nations Security Council Resolution 2334</a>, which condemned <a href="/wiki/Israeli_settlement" title="Israeli settlement">Israeli settlement building</a> in the occupied <a href="/wiki/Palestinian_territories" title="Palestinian territories">Palestinian territories</a> as a violation of international law, effectively allowing it to pass.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-376"><a href="#cite_note-376">[376]</a></sup> Netanyahu strongly criticized the Obama Administration's actions,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-377"><a href="#cite_note-377">[377]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-378"><a href="#cite_note-378">[378]</a></sup> and the Israeli government withdrew its annual dues from the organization, which totaled $6 million, on January 6, 2017.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-379"><a href="#cite_note-379">[379]</a></sup> On January 5, 2017, the <a href="/wiki/United_States_House_of_Representatives" title="United States House of Representatives">United States House of Representatives</a> voted 342‚Äì80 to condemn the UN Resolution.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-380"><a href="#cite_note-380">[380]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-381"><a href="#cite_note-381">[381]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Libya">Libya</span></h4>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/2011_military_intervention_in_Libya" title="2011 military intervention in Libya">2011 military intervention in Libya</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Vladimir_Putin_and_Barack_Obama_(2015-09-29)_04.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1160" data-file-width="1880" decoding="async" height="136" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Vladimir_Putin_and_Barack_Obama_%282015-09-29%29_04.jpg/220px-Vladimir_Putin_and_Barack_Obama_%282015-09-29%29_04.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Vladimir_Putin_and_Barack_Obama_%282015-09-29%29_04.jpg/330px-Vladimir_Putin_and_Barack_Obama_%282015-09-29%29_04.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Vladimir_Putin_and_Barack_Obama_%282015-09-29%29_04.jpg/440px-Vladimir_Putin_and_Barack_Obama_%282015-09-29%29_04.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Vladimir_Putin_and_Barack_Obama_(2015-09-29)_04.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>President Obama meets with Russian President <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Putin" title="Vladimir Putin">Vladimir Putin</a> to discuss Syria and ISIS, September 29, 2015.</div></div></div>
<p>In February 2011, protests in Libya began against long-time dictator <a href="/wiki/Muammar_Gaddafi" title="Muammar Gaddafi">Muammar Gaddafi</a> as part of the <a href="/wiki/Arab_Spring" title="Arab Spring">Arab Spring</a>. They soon turned violent. In March, as forces loyal to Gaddafi advanced on rebels across Libya, calls for a no-fly zone came from around the world, including Europe, the <a href="/wiki/Arab_League" title="Arab League">Arab League</a>, and a resolution<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-382"><a href="#cite_note-382">[382]</a></sup> passed unanimously by the U.S. Senate.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-383"><a href="#cite_note-383">[383]</a></sup> In response to the unanimous passage of <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council_Resolution_1973" title="United Nations Security Council Resolution 1973">United Nations Security Council Resolution 1973</a> on March 17, Gaddafi‚Äîwho had previously vowed to "show no mercy" to the rebels of Benghazi<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-384"><a href="#cite_note-384">[384]</a></sup>‚Äîannounced an immediate cessation of military activities,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-385"><a href="#cite_note-385">[385]</a></sup> yet reports came in that his forces continued shelling <a href="/wiki/Misrata" title="Misrata">Misrata</a>. The next day, on Obama's orders, the U.S. military took part in air strikes to destroy the Libyan government's air defense capabilities to protect civilians and enforce a no-fly-zone,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-386"><a href="#cite_note-386">[386]</a></sup> including the use of <a href="/wiki/Tomahawk_(missile)" title="Tomahawk (missile)">Tomahawk missiles</a>, <a href="/wiki/Northrop_Grumman_B-2_Spirit" title="Northrop Grumman B-2 Spirit">B-2 Spirits</a>, and fighter jets.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-387"><a href="#cite_note-387">[387]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-388"><a href="#cite_note-388">[388]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-389"><a href="#cite_note-389">[389]</a></sup> Six days later, on March 25, by unanimous vote of all its 28 members, <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a> took over leadership of the effort, dubbed <a href="/wiki/Operation_Unified_Protector" title="Operation Unified Protector">Operation Unified Protector</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NATOPressRelease_390-0"><a href="#cite_note-NATOPressRelease-390">[390]</a></sup> Some Representatives<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LibyaOffensive_391-0"><a href="#cite_note-LibyaOffensive-391">[391]</a></sup> questioned whether Obama had the constitutional authority to order military action in addition to questioning its cost, structure and aftermath.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-392"><a href="#cite_note-392">[392]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-393"><a href="#cite_note-393">[393]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Syrian_Civil_War">Syrian Civil War</span></h4>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_involvement_in_the_Syrian_Civil_War#United_States" title="Foreign involvement in the Syrian Civil War">Foreign involvement in the Syrian Civil War ¬ß¬†United States</a></div>
<p>On August 18, 2011, several months after the start of the <a href="/wiki/Syrian_Civil_War" title="Syrian Civil War">Syrian Civil War</a>, Obama issued a written statement that said: "The time has come for <a href="/wiki/Bashar_al-Assad" title="Bashar al-Assad">President Assad</a> to step aside."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mustgo_394-0"><a href="#cite_note-mustgo-394">[394]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-whstatem_395-0"><a href="#cite_note-whstatem-395">[395]</a></sup> This stance was reaffirmed in November 2015.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-396"><a href="#cite_note-396">[396]</a></sup> In 2012, Obama authorized multiple <a href="/wiki/Timber_Sycamore" title="Timber Sycamore">programs run by the CIA</a> and the Pentagon to train anti-Assad rebels.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-397"><a href="#cite_note-397">[397]</a></sup> The Pentagon-run program was later found to have failed and was formally abandoned in October 2015.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-398"><a href="#cite_note-398">[398]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-399"><a href="#cite_note-399">[399]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the wake of a <a href="/wiki/Ghouta_chemical_attack" title="Ghouta chemical attack">chemical weapons attack</a> in Syria, <a href="/wiki/U.S._Government_Assessment_of_the_Syrian_Government%27s_Use_of_Chemical_Weapons_on_August_21,_2013" title="U.S. Government Assessment of the Syrian Government's Use of Chemical Weapons on August 21, 2013">formally blamed</a> by the Obama administration on the Assad government, Obama chose not to enforce the "red line" he had pledged<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-redline_400-0"><a href="#cite_note-redline-400">[400]</a></sup> and, rather than authorize the promised military action against Assad, went along with the Russia-brokered deal that led to Assad <a href="/wiki/Destruction_of_Syria%27s_chemical_weapons" title="Destruction of Syria's chemical weapons">giving up chemical weapons</a>; however attacks with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chlorine_gas" title="Chlorine gas">chlorine gas</a> continued.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-401"><a href="#cite_note-401">[401]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-402"><a href="#cite_note-402">[402]</a></sup> In 2014, Obama authorized an <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Military_intervention_against_ISIL" title="Military intervention against ISIL">air campaign aimed primarily at ISIL</a>, but repeatedly promised the U.S. would not deploy ground troops in Syria.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-403"><a href="#cite_note-403">[403]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-404"><a href="#cite_note-404">[404]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Death_of_Osama_bin_Laden">Death of Osama bin Laden</span></h4>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Death_of_Osama_bin_Laden" title="Death of Osama bin Laden">Death of Osama bin Laden</a></div>
