<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Obama_and_Biden_await_updates_on_bin_Laden.jpg"><img alt="President Barack Obama and Vice President Joe Biden, along with members of the national security team, receive an update on Operation Neptune's Spear, a mission against Osama bin Laden, in one of the conference rooms of the Situation Room of the White House, on May 1, 2011. They are watching live feed from drones operating over the bin Laden complex." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2731" data-file-width="4096" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Obama_and_Biden_await_updates_on_bin_Laden.jpg/220px-Obama_and_Biden_await_updates_on_bin_Laden.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Obama_and_Biden_await_updates_on_bin_Laden.jpg/330px-Obama_and_Biden_await_updates_on_bin_Laden.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Obama_and_Biden_await_updates_on_bin_Laden.jpg/440px-Obama_and_Biden_await_updates_on_bin_Laden.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Obama_and_Biden_await_updates_on_bin_Laden.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Obama and members of the national security team receive an update on <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Operation_Neptune%27s_Spear" title="Operation Neptune's Spear">Operation Neptune's Spear</a> in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/White_House_Situation_Room" title="White House Situation Room">White House Situation Room</a>, May 1, 2011. See also: <a href="/wiki/Situation_Room_(photograph)" title="Situation Room (photograph)"><i>Situation Room</i></a></div></div></div>
<p>Starting with information received from Central Intelligence Agency operatives in July 2010, the CIA developed intelligence over the next several months that determined what they believed to be the hideout of <a href="/wiki/Osama_bin_Laden" title="Osama bin Laden">Osama bin Laden</a>. He was living in seclusion in <a href="/wiki/Osama_bin_Laden%27s_compound_in_Abbottabad" title="Osama bin Laden's compound in Abbottabad">a large compound</a> in <a href="/wiki/Abbottabad" title="Abbottabad">Abbottabad</a>, Pakistan, a suburban area 35 miles (56¬†km) from <a href="/wiki/Islamabad" title="Islamabad">Islamabad</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT-clues_405-0"><a href="#cite_note-NYT-clues-405">[405]</a></sup> CIA head <a href="/wiki/Leon_Panetta" title="Leon Panetta">Leon Panetta</a> reported this intelligence to President Obama in March 2011.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT-clues_405-1"><a href="#cite_note-NYT-clues-405">[405]</a></sup> Meeting with his national security advisers over the course of the next six weeks, Obama rejected a plan to bomb the compound, and authorized a "surgical raid" to be conducted by <a href="/wiki/United_States_Navy_SEALs" title="United States Navy SEALs">United States Navy SEALs</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT-clues_405-2"><a href="#cite_note-NYT-clues-405">[405]</a></sup> The operation took place on May 1, 2011, and resulted in the shooting death of bin Laden and the seizure of papers, computer drives and disks from the compound.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WP-binLaden_406-0"><a href="#cite_note-WP-binLaden-406">[406]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ND-binLaden_407-0"><a href="#cite_note-ND-binLaden-407">[407]</a></sup> DNA testing was one of five methods used to positively identify bin Laden's corpse,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ABC-binLaden_408-0"><a href="#cite_note-ABC-binLaden-408">[408]</a></sup> which was buried at sea several hours later.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT-ObamaAnnounce_409-0"><a href="#cite_note-NYT-ObamaAnnounce-409">[409]</a></sup> Within minutes of the President's announcement from Washington, DC, late in the evening on May 1, there were spontaneous celebrations around the country as crowds gathered outside the White House, and at New York City's <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Center_site" title="World Trade Center site">Ground Zero</a> and <a href="/wiki/Times_Square" title="Times Square">Times Square</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WP-binLaden_406-1"><a href="#cite_note-WP-binLaden-406">[406]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Guard-ObamaAnnounce_410-0"><a href="#cite_note-Guard-ObamaAnnounce-410">[410]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Reactions_to_the_death_of_Osama_bin_Laden" title="Reactions to the death of Osama bin Laden">Reaction to the announcement</a> was positive across party lines, including from former presidents Bill Clinton and George W. Bush.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bloom-binLaden_411-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bloom-binLaden-411">[411]</a></sup>
</p>
<div style="clear:both;"></div>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Iran_nuclear_talks">Iran nuclear talks</span></h4>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Joint_Comprehensive_Plan_of_Action" title="Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action">Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Barack_Obama_talks_with_Benjamin_Netanyahu_(8637772147).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2730" data-file-width="4096" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Barack_Obama_talks_with_Benjamin_Netanyahu_%288637772147%29.jpg/220px-Barack_Obama_talks_with_Benjamin_Netanyahu_%288637772147%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Barack_Obama_talks_with_Benjamin_Netanyahu_%288637772147%29.jpg/330px-Barack_Obama_talks_with_Benjamin_Netanyahu_%288637772147%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Barack_Obama_talks_with_Benjamin_Netanyahu_%288637772147%29.jpg/440px-Barack_Obama_talks_with_Benjamin_Netanyahu_%288637772147%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Barack_Obama_talks_with_Benjamin_Netanyahu_(8637772147).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Obama talks with Benjamin Netanyahu, March 2013.</div></div></div>
<p>In November 2013, the Obama administration opened <a href="/wiki/Negotiations_leading_to_the_Joint_Comprehensive_Plan_of_Action" title="Negotiations leading to the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action">negotiations</a> with Iran to prevent it from acquiring <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_weapon" title="Nuclear weapon">nuclear weapons</a>, which included an <a href="/wiki/Joint_Plan_of_Action" title="Joint Plan of Action">interim agreement</a>. Negotiations took two years with numerous delays, with a deal being announced July 14, 2015. The deal, titled the "<a href="/wiki/Joint_Comprehensive_Plan_of_Action" title="Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action">Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action</a>", saw the removal of sanctions in exchange for measures that would prevent Iran from producing nuclear weapons. While Obama hailed the agreement as being a step towards a more hopeful world, the deal drew strong criticism from Republican and conservative quarters, and from Israeli prime minister <a href="/wiki/Benjamin_Netanyahu" title="Benjamin Netanyahu">Benjamin Netanyahu</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-412"><a href="#cite_note-412">[412]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-413"><a href="#cite_note-413">[413]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-414"><a href="#cite_note-414">[414]</a></sup> In addition, the transfer of $1.7 billion in cash to Iran shortly after the deal was announced was criticized by the republican party. The Obama administration said that the payment in cash was because of the "effectiveness of U.S. and international sanctions".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-415"><a href="#cite_note-415">[415]</a></sup> In order to advance the deal, the Obama administration shielded <a href="/wiki/Hezbollah" title="Hezbollah">Hezbollah</a> from the <a href="/wiki/Drug_Enforcement_Administration" title="Drug Enforcement Administration">Drug Enforcement Administration</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Project_Cassandra" title="Project Cassandra">Project Cassandra</a> investigation regarding drug smuggling and from the <a href="/wiki/Central_Intelligence_Agency" title="Central Intelligence Agency">Central Intelligence Agency</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-416"><a href="#cite_note-416">[416]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-417"><a href="#cite_note-417">[417]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Relations_with_Cuba">Relations with Cuba</span></h4>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_States%E2%80%93Cuban_Thaw" title="United States‚ÄìCuban Thaw">United States‚ÄìCuban Thaw</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Handshake_between_the_President_and_Cuban_President_Ra%C3%BAl_Castro.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1000" data-file-width="1500" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Handshake_between_the_President_and_Cuban_President_Ra%C3%BAl_Castro.jpg/220px-Handshake_between_the_President_and_Cuban_President_Ra%C3%BAl_Castro.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Handshake_between_the_President_and_Cuban_President_Ra%C3%BAl_Castro.jpg/330px-Handshake_between_the_President_and_Cuban_President_Ra%C3%BAl_Castro.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Handshake_between_the_President_and_Cuban_President_Ra%C3%BAl_Castro.jpg/440px-Handshake_between_the_President_and_Cuban_President_Ra%C3%BAl_Castro.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Handshake_between_the_President_and_Cuban_President_Ra%C3%BAl_Castro.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>President Obama meeting with Cuban President <a href="/wiki/Ra%C3%BAl_Castro" title="Ra√∫l Castro">Ra√∫l Castro</a> in Panama, April 2015</div></div></div>
<p>Since the spring of 2013, secret meetings were conducted between the United States and Cuba in the neutral locations of Canada and <a href="/wiki/Vatican_City" title="Vatican City">Vatican City</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-418"><a href="#cite_note-418">[418]</a></sup> The Vatican first became involved in 2013 when <a href="/wiki/Pope_Francis" title="Pope Francis">Pope Francis</a> advised the U.S. and Cuba to <a href="/wiki/Prisoner_exchange" title="Prisoner exchange">exchange prisoners</a> as a gesture of goodwill.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-419"><a href="#cite_note-419">[419]</a></sup> On December 10, 2013, Cuban President <a href="/wiki/Ra%C3%BAl_Castro" title="Ra√∫l Castro">Ra√∫l Castro</a>, in a significant public moment, greeted and shook hands with Obama at the <a href="/wiki/Death_of_Nelson_Mandela" title="Death of Nelson Mandela">Nelson Mandela memorial service</a> in <a href="/wiki/Johannesburg" title="Johannesburg">Johannesburg</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-420"><a href="#cite_note-420">[420]</a></sup>
</p><p>In December 2014, after the secret meetings, it was announced that Obama, with <a href="/wiki/Pope_Francis" title="Pope Francis">Pope Francis</a> as an intermediary, had negotiated a restoration of relations with Cuba, after nearly sixty years of d√©tente.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-421"><a href="#cite_note-421">[421]</a></sup> Popularly dubbed the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cuban_Thaw" title="Cuban Thaw">Cuban Thaw</a>, <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_Republic" title="The New Republic">The New Republic</a></i> deemed the Cuban Thaw to be "Obama's finest foreign policy achievement."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-422"><a href="#cite_note-422">[422]</a></sup> On July 1, 2015, President Barack Obama announced that formal diplomatic relations between Cuba and the United States would resume, and embassies would be opened in Washington and <a href="/wiki/Havana" title="Havana">Havana</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-423"><a href="#cite_note-423">[423]</a></sup> The countries' respective "interests sections" in one another's capitals were upgraded to embassies on July 20 and August 13, 2015, respectively.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-424"><a href="#cite_note-424">[424]</a></sup>
</p><p>Obama visited Havana, Cuba for two days in March 2016, becoming the first sitting U.S. President to arrive since <a href="/wiki/Calvin_Coolidge" title="Calvin Coolidge">Calvin Coolidge</a> in 1928.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-425"><a href="#cite_note-425">[425]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Africa">Africa</span></h4>
<p>Obama spoke in front of the <a href="/wiki/African_Union" title="African Union">African Union</a> in <a href="/wiki/Addis_Ababa" title="Addis Ababa">Addis Ababa</a>, Ethiopia, on July 29, 2015, the first sitting U.S. president to do so. He gave a speech encouraging the world to increase economic ties via investments and trade with the continent, and lauded the progress made in <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Africa" title="Education in Africa">education</a>, infrastructure, and <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Africa" title="Economy of Africa">economy</a>. He also criticized the lack of democracy and leaders who refuse to step aside, discrimination against minorities (<a href="/wiki/LGBT" title="LGBT">LGBT</a> people, religious groups and ethnicities), and corruption. He suggested an intensified <a href="/wiki/Democratization" title="Democratization">democratization</a> and free trade, to significantly improve the quality of life for Africans.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-426"><a href="#cite_note-426">[426]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-427"><a href="#cite_note-427">[427]</a></sup> During his July 2015 trip, Obama also was the first U.S. president ever to <a href="/wiki/United_States_presidential_visits_to_Sub-Saharan_Africa" title="United States presidential visits to Sub-Saharan Africa">visit</a> Kenya, which is the homeland of his father.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-428"><a href="#cite_note-428">[428]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Hiroshima_speech">Hiroshima speech</span></h4>
<p>On May 27, 2016, Obama became the first sitting American president to visit <a href="/wiki/Hiroshima" title="Hiroshima">Hiroshima</a>, Japan, 71 years after the <a href="/wiki/Atomic_bombings_of_Hiroshima_and_Nagasaki" title="Atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki">U.S. atomic bombing of Hiroshima</a> that ended <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>. Accompanied by Japanese Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Shinz%C5%8D_Abe" title="Shinz≈ç Abe">Shinz≈ç Abe</a>, Obama paid tribute to the victims of the bombing at the <a href="/wiki/Hiroshima_Peace_Memorial_Museum" title="Hiroshima Peace Memorial Museum">Hiroshima Peace Memorial Museum</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-429"><a href="#cite_note-429">[429]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Russia">Russia</span></h4>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Russia%E2%80%93United_States_relations#Obama's_tenure_(2009‚Äì17)" title="Russia‚ÄìUnited States relations">Russia‚ÄìUnited States relations ¬ß¬†Obama's tenure (2009‚Äì17)</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Vladimir_Putin_and_Barack_Obama_(2015-09-29)_01.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1160" data-file-width="1880" decoding="async" height="136" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Vladimir_Putin_and_Barack_Obama_%282015-09-29%29_01.jpg/220px-Vladimir_Putin_and_Barack_Obama_%282015-09-29%29_01.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Vladimir_Putin_and_Barack_Obama_%282015-09-29%29_01.jpg/330px-Vladimir_Putin_and_Barack_Obama_%282015-09-29%29_01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Vladimir_Putin_and_Barack_Obama_%282015-09-29%29_01.jpg/440px-Vladimir_Putin_and_Barack_Obama_%282015-09-29%29_01.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Vladimir_Putin_and_Barack_Obama_(2015-09-29)_01.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Obama meets Russian President <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Putin" title="Vladimir Putin">Vladimir Putin</a> in September 2015.</div></div></div>
<p>After <a href="/wiki/Annexation_of_Crimea_by_the_Russian_Federation" title="Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation">Russia's invasion of Crimea</a> in 2014, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Russian_military_intervention_in_Syria" title="Russian military intervention in Syria">military intervention</a> in Syria in 2015, and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2016_United_States_election_interference_by_Russia" title="2016 United States election interference by Russia">interference</a> in the <a href="/wiki/2016_United_States_presidential_election" title="2016 United States presidential election">2016 U.S. presidential election</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ftelect_430-0"><a href="#cite_note-ftelect-430">[430]</a></sup> Obama's Russia policy was widely seen as a failure.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-friedmnyt_431-0"><a href="#cite_note-friedmnyt-431">[431]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/George_Robertson,_Baron_Robertson_of_Port_Ellen" title="George Robertson, Baron Robertson of Port Ellen">George Robertson</a>, a former UK defense secretary and NATO secretary-general, said Obama had "allowed Putin to jump back on the world stage and test the resolve of the West", adding that the legacy of this disaster would last.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-obexit_432-0"><a href="#cite_note-obexit-432">[432]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cultural_and_political_image">Cultural and political image</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Public_image_of_Barack_Obama" title="Public image of Barack Obama">Public image of Barack Obama</a></div>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/International_reactions_to_the_2008_United_States_presidential_election" title="International reactions to the 2008 United States presidential election">International reactions to the 2008 United States presidential election</a> and <a href="/wiki/International_reactions_to_the_2012_United_States_presidential_election" title="International reactions to the 2012 United States presidential election">International reactions to the 2012 United States presidential election</a></div>
<p>Obama's family history, upbringing, and <a href="/wiki/Ivy_League" title="Ivy League">Ivy League</a> education differ markedly from those of African-American politicians who launched their careers in the 1960s through participation in the <a href="/wiki/Civil_rights_movement" title="Civil rights movement">civil rights movement</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-433"><a href="#cite_note-433">[433]</a></sup> Expressing puzzlement over questions about whether he is "black enough", Obama told an August 2007 meeting of the <a href="/wiki/National_Association_of_Black_Journalists" title="National Association of Black Journalists">National Association of Black Journalists</a> that "we're still locked in this notion that if you appeal to white folks then there must be something wrong."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-434"><a href="#cite_note-434">[434]</a></sup> Obama acknowledged his youthful image in an October 2007 campaign speech, saying: "I wouldn't be here if, time and again, the torch had not been passed to a new generation."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-435"><a href="#cite_note-435">[435]</a></sup>
</p><p>Obama is frequently referred to as an exceptional orator.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-exceptional_orator_436-0"><a href="#cite_note-exceptional_orator-436">[436]</a></sup> During his pre-inauguration transition period and continuing into his presidency, Obama delivered a series of weekly Internet video addresses.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-437"><a href="#cite_note-437">[437]</a></sup> In his speeches as president, Obama did not make more overt references to race relations than his predecessors,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-438"><a href="#cite_note-438">[438]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-439"><a href="#cite_note-439">[439]</a></sup> but according to one study, he implemented stronger policy action on behalf of African-Americans than any president since the Nixon era.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-440"><a href="#cite_note-440">[440]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Gallup_Poll-Approval_Rating-Barack_Obama.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="349" data-file-width="650" decoding="async" height="118" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Gallup_Poll-Approval_Rating-Barack_Obama.svg/220px-Gallup_Poll-Approval_Rating-Barack_Obama.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Gallup_Poll-Approval_Rating-Barack_Obama.svg/330px-Gallup_Poll-Approval_Rating-Barack_Obama.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Gallup_Poll-Approval_Rating-Barack_Obama.svg/440px-Gallup_Poll-Approval_Rating-Barack_Obama.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Gallup_Poll-Approval_Rating-Barack_Obama.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Presidential approval ratings</div></div></div>
<p>According to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gallup_Organization" title="Gallup Organization">Gallup Organization</a>, Obama began his presidency with a 68% approval rating<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-441"><a href="#cite_note-441">[441]</a></sup> before gradually declining for the rest of the year, and eventually bottoming out at 41% in August 2010,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-442"><a href="#cite_note-442">[442]</a></sup> a trend similar to <a href="/wiki/Ronald_Reagan" title="Ronald Reagan">Ronald Reagan</a>'s and <a href="/wiki/Bill_Clinton" title="Bill Clinton">Bill Clinton</a>'s first years in office.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-443"><a href="#cite_note-443">[443]</a></sup> He experienced a small poll bounce shortly after the <a href="/wiki/Death_of_Osama_bin_Laden" title="Death of Osama bin Laden">death of Osama bin Laden</a> on May 2, 2011. This bounce lasted until around June 2011, when his approval numbers dropped back to where they were previously.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-444"><a href="#cite_note-444">[444]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-445"><a href="#cite_note-445">[445]</a></sup> His approval ratings rebounded around the same time as his reelection in 2012, with polls showing an average job approval of 52% shortly after his second inauguration.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-446"><a href="#cite_note-446">[446]</a></sup> Despite approval ratings dropping to 39% in late-2013 due to the ACA roll-out, they climbed to 50% in January 2015 according to Gallup.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-447"><a href="#cite_note-447">[447]</a></sup>
</p><p>Polls showed strong support for Obama in other countries both before and during his presidency.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-448"><a href="#cite_note-448">[448]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-449"><a href="#cite_note-449">[449]</a></sup> In a February 2009 poll conducted in Western Europe and the U.S. by <a href="/wiki/Harris_Insights_%26_Analytics" title="Harris Insights &amp; Analytics">Harris Interactive</a> for <a href="/wiki/France_24" title="France 24">France 24</a> and the <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/International_Herald_Tribune" title="International Herald Tribune">International Herald Tribune</a></i>, Obama was rated as the most respected world leader, as well as the most powerful.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-450"><a href="#cite_note-450">[450]</a></sup> In a similar poll conducted by Harris in May 2009, Obama was rated as the most popular world leader, as well as the one figure most people would pin their hopes on for pulling the world out of the economic downturn.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-451"><a href="#cite_note-451">[451]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-452"><a href="#cite_note-452">[452]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:G8_leaders_watching_football.jpg"><img alt="Prime Minister David Cameron of the United Kingdom, President Barack Obama, Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany, Jos√© Manuel Barroso, President of the European Commission, President Fran√ßois Hollande of France and others react emotionally while watching the overtime shootout of the Chelsea vs. Bayern Munich Champions League final, in the Laurel Cabin conference room during the G8 Summit at Camp David, Maryland, May 19, 2012. Cameron raises his arms triumphantly as the Chelsea team wins their first Champions League title in the overtime shootout." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2629" data-file-width="4021" decoding="async" height="144" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/G8_leaders_watching_football.jpg/220px-G8_leaders_watching_football.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/G8_leaders_watching_football.jpg/330px-G8_leaders_watching_football.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/G8_leaders_watching_football.jpg/440px-G8_leaders_watching_football.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:G8_leaders_watching_football.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>G8 leaders watching the <a href="/wiki/2012_UEFA_Champions_League_Final" title="2012 UEFA Champions League Final">2012 UEFA Champions League Final</a></div></div></div>
<p>Obama won <a href="/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Best_Spoken_Word_Album" title="Grammy Award for Best Spoken Word Album">Best Spoken Word Album</a> <a href="/wiki/Grammy_Award" title="Grammy Award">Grammy Awards</a> for abridged <a href="/wiki/Audiobook" title="Audiobook">audiobook</a> versions of <i><a href="/wiki/Dreams_from_My_Father" title="Dreams from My Father">Dreams from My Father</a></i> in February 2006 and for <i><a href="/wiki/The_Audacity_of_Hope" title="The Audacity of Hope">The Audacity of Hope</a></i> in February 2008.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-453"><a href="#cite_note-453">[453]</a></sup> His <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Barack_Obama_presidential_primary_campaign,_2008#New_Hampshire" title="Barack Obama presidential primary campaign, 2008">concession speech</a> after the New Hampshire primary was set to music by independent artists as the music video "<a href="/wiki/Yes_We_Can_(will.i.am_song)" title="Yes We Can (will.i.am song)">Yes We Can</a>", which was viewed 10¬†million times on YouTube in its first month<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-454"><a href="#cite_note-454">[454]</a></sup> and received a <a href="/wiki/Daytime_Emmy_Award" title="Daytime Emmy Award">Daytime Emmy Award</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-455"><a href="#cite_note-455">[455]</a></sup> In December 2008 and in 2012, <i><a href="/wiki/Time_(magazine)" title="Time (magazine)">Time</a></i> magazine named Obama as its <a href="/wiki/Time_Person_of_the_Year" title="Time Person of the Year">Person of the Year</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-456"><a href="#cite_note-456">[456]</a></sup> The 2008 awarding was for his historic candidacy and election, which <i>Time</i> described as "the steady march of seemingly impossible accomplishments".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-457"><a href="#cite_note-457">[457]</a></sup> On May 25, 2011, Obama became the first President of the United States to address both houses of the <a href="/wiki/Parliament_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Parliament of the United Kingdom">UK Parliament</a> in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Westminster_Hall" title="Westminster Hall">Westminster Hall</a>, London. This was only the fifth occurrence since the start of the 20th century of a head of state's being extended this invitation, following <a href="/wiki/Charles_de_Gaulle" title="Charles de Gaulle">Charles de Gaulle</a> in 1960, <a href="/wiki/Nelson_Mandela" title="Nelson Mandela">Nelson Mandela</a> in 1996, <a href="/wiki/Elizabeth_II" title="Elizabeth II">Queen Elizabeth II</a> in 2002 and <a href="/wiki/Pope_Benedict_XVI" title="Pope Benedict XVI">Pope Benedict XVI</a> in 2010.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-458"><a href="#cite_note-458">[458]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-459"><a href="#cite_note-459">[459]</a></sup>
</p><p>On October 9, 2009, the <a href="/wiki/Norwegian_Nobel_Committee" title="Norwegian Nobel Committee">Norwegian Nobel Committee</a> announced that Obama had won the <a href="/wiki/2009_Nobel_Peace_Prize" title="2009 Nobel Peace Prize">2009 Nobel Peace Prize</a> "for his extraordinary efforts to strengthen international diplomacy and cooperation between peoples".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nobel_peace_prize_460-0"><a href="#cite_note-nobel_peace_prize-460">[460]</a></sup> Obama accepted this award in <a href="/wiki/Oslo" title="Oslo">Oslo</a>, Norway on December 10, 2009, with "deep gratitude and great humility."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CNN:_Obama_acceptance_transcript_461-0"><a href="#cite_note-CNN:_Obama_acceptance_transcript-461">[461]</a></sup> The award drew a mixture of praise and criticism from world leaders and media figures.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-462"><a href="#cite_note-462">[462]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-463"><a href="#cite_note-463">[463]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-464"><a href="#cite_note-464">[464]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-465"><a href="#cite_note-465">[465]</a></sup> Obama's peace prize was called a "stunning surprise" by <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">The New York Times</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-466"><a href="#cite_note-466">[466]</a></sup> Obama is the fourth U.S. president to be awarded the Nobel Peace Prize and the third to become a Nobel laureate while in office.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-467"><a href="#cite_note-467">[467]</a></sup> Obama's Nobel Prize has been viewed skeptically in subsequent years, especially after the director of the Nobel Institute, <a href="/wiki/Geir_Lundestad" title="Geir Lundestad">Geir Lundestad</a>, said Obama's Peace Prize did not have the desired effect.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-468"><a href="#cite_note-468">[468]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span id="Post-presidency_.282017.E2.80.93present.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Post-presidency_(2017‚Äìpresent)">Post-presidency (2017‚Äìpresent)</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:58th_Presidential_Inaugural_Ceremony_170120-D-BP749-1327.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2576" data-file-width="3863" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/58th_Presidential_Inaugural_Ceremony_170120-D-BP749-1327.jpg/220px-58th_Presidential_Inaugural_Ceremony_170120-D-BP749-1327.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/58th_Presidential_Inaugural_Ceremony_170120-D-BP749-1327.jpg/330px-58th_Presidential_Inaugural_Ceremony_170120-D-BP749-1327.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/58th_Presidential_Inaugural_Ceremony_170120-D-BP749-1327.jpg/440px-58th_Presidential_Inaugural_Ceremony_170120-D-BP749-1327.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:58th_Presidential_Inaugural_Ceremony_170120-D-BP749-1327.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Obama, with <a href="/wiki/Joe_Biden" title="Joe Biden">Joe Biden</a> and <a href="/wiki/Donald_Trump" title="Donald Trump">Donald Trump</a> at the latter's <a href="/wiki/Inauguration_of_Donald_Trump" title="Inauguration of Donald Trump">inauguration</a> on January 20, 2017</div></div></div>
<p>Obama's presidency ended at noon on January 20, 2017, immediately following the <a href="/wiki/Inauguration_of_Donald_Trump" title="Inauguration of Donald Trump">inauguration</a> of his Republican successor, <a href="/wiki/Donald_Trump" title="Donald Trump">Donald Trump</a>. After the inauguration, Obama lifted off on <a href="/wiki/Executive_One" title="Executive One">Executive One</a>, circled the White House, and flew to <a href="/wiki/Joint_Base_Andrews" title="Joint Base Andrews">Joint Base Andrews</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-469"><a href="#cite_note-469">[469]</a></sup> The family currently rents a house in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kalorama,_Washington,_D.C." title="Kalorama, Washington, D.C.">Kalorama, Washington, D.C.</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-470"><a href="#cite_note-470">[470]</a></sup>
</p><p>On March 2, 2017, the <a href="/wiki/John_F._Kennedy_Presidential_Library_and_Museum" title="John F. Kennedy Presidential Library and Museum">John F. Kennedy Presidential Library and Museum</a> awarded the annual <a href="/wiki/Profile_in_Courage_Award" title="Profile in Courage Award">Profile in Courage Award</a> to Obama "for his enduring commitment to democratic ideals and elevating the standard of political courage."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-471"><a href="#cite_note-471">[471]</a></sup> In his first public appearance out of office, Obama appeared at a seminar at the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Chicago" title="University of Chicago">University of Chicago</a> on April 24. The seminar was aimed at the engagement with a new generation as well as an appeal for their participation in politics.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-472"><a href="#cite_note-472">[472]</a></sup> On May 4, three days ahead of the <a href="/wiki/2017_French_presidential_election" title="2017 French presidential election">French presidential election</a>, Obama publicly endorsed <a href="/wiki/Emmanuel_Macron" title="Emmanuel Macron">Emmanuel Macron</a>: "He appeals to people's hopes and not their fears, and I enjoyed speaking to Emmanuel recently to hear about his independent movement and his vision for the future of France."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-473"><a href="#cite_note-473">[473]</a></sup> Macron went on to win the election.
</p><p>While in <a href="/wiki/Berlin" title="Berlin">Berlin</a> on May 25, Obama made a joint public appearance with Chancellor <a href="/wiki/Angela_Merkel" title="Angela Merkel">Angela Merkel</a> where he stressed inclusion and for leaders to question themselves, Obama having been formally invited to Berlin while still in office as part of an effort to boost Merkel's re-election campaign.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-474"><a href="#cite_note-474">[474]</a></sup> Obama traveled to <a href="/wiki/Kensington_Palace" title="Kensington Palace">Kensington Palace</a> in England and met with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Prince_Harry" title="Prince Harry">Prince Harry</a> on May 27, 2017; Obama tweeted afterward that the two discussed their foundations and offering condolences in the wake of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2017_Manchester_Arena_bombing" title="2017 Manchester Arena bombing">Manchester Arena bombing</a> that occurred five days prior.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-475"><a href="#cite_note-475">[475]</a></sup>
</p><p>After President Trump announced his withdrawal of the United States from the <a href="/wiki/Paris_Agreement" title="Paris Agreement">Paris Agreement</a> on June 1, Obama released a statement disagreeing with the choice: "But even in the absence of American leadership; even as this administration joins a small handful of nations that reject the future; I'm confident that our states, cities, and businesses will step up and do even more to lead the way, and help protect for future generations the one planet we've got."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-476"><a href="#cite_note-476">[476]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Obama_Macri_October_2017.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1351" data-file-width="1940" decoding="async" height="153" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/Obama_Macri_October_2017.jpg/220px-Obama_Macri_October_2017.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/Obama_Macri_October_2017.jpg/330px-Obama_Macri_October_2017.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/Obama_Macri_October_2017.jpg/440px-Obama_Macri_October_2017.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Obama_Macri_October_2017.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Obama playing golf with the President of Argentina <a href="/wiki/Mauricio_Macri" title="Mauricio Macri">Mauricio Macri</a>, October 2017</div></div></div>
<p>After Senate Republicans revealed the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Better_Care_Reconciliation_Act_of_2017" title="Better Care Reconciliation Act of 2017">Better Care Reconciliation Act of 2017</a>, their discussion draft of a health care bill to replace the Affordable Care Act, on June 22, Obama released a Facebook post calling the bill "a massive transfer of wealth from middle-class and poor families to the richest people in America."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-477"><a href="#cite_note-477">[477]</a></sup> On September 19, while delivering the keynote address at Goalkeepers, Obama admitted his frustration with Republicans backing "a bill that will raise costs, reduce coverage, and roll back protections for older Americans and people with pre-existing conditions".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-478"><a href="#cite_note-478">[478]</a></sup>
</p><p>After Attorney General <a href="/wiki/Jeff_Sessions" title="Jeff Sessions">Jeff Sessions</a> announced the termination of the <a href="/wiki/Deferred_Action_for_Childhood_Arrivals" title="Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals">Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals</a> (DACA) program on September 5, Obama released a Facebook post rebuking the decision.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-479"><a href="#cite_note-479">[479]</a></sup> Two days later, he partnered with former presidents <a href="/wiki/Jimmy_Carter" title="Jimmy Carter">Jimmy Carter</a>, <a href="/wiki/George_H._W._Bush" title="George H. W. Bush">George H. W. Bush</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bill_Clinton" title="Bill Clinton">Bill Clinton</a>, and <a href="/wiki/George_W._Bush" title="George W. Bush">George W. Bush</a> to work with <a href="/wiki/One_America_Appeal" title="One America Appeal">One America Appeal</a> to help the victims of <a href="/wiki/Hurricane_Harvey" title="Hurricane Harvey">Hurricane Harvey</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hurricane_Irma" title="Hurricane Irma">Hurricane Irma</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Gulf_Coast_of_the_United_States" title="Gulf Coast of the United States">Gulf Coast</a> and <a href="/wiki/Texas" title="Texas">Texas</a> communities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-480"><a href="#cite_note-480">[480]</a></sup>
</p><p>Obama hosted the inaugural summit of the <a href="/wiki/Obama_Foundation" title="Obama Foundation">Obama Foundation</a> in Chicago on October 31. Obama intends for the foundation to be the central focus of his post-presidency and part of his ambitions for his subsequent activities following his presidency to be more consequential than his time in office.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-481"><a href="#cite_note-481">[481]</a></sup> Obama has also been working on a Presidential memoir, in a reported $65 million deal with <a href="/wiki/Penguin_Random_House" title="Penguin Random House">Penguin Random House</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nymag_482-0"><a href="#cite_note-nymag-482">[482]</a></sup>
</p><p>Obama went on an international trip from November 28 to December 2, 2017, and visited China, India and France. In China, he delivered remarks at the Global Alliance of SMEs Summit in Shanghai and met with Chinese President <a href="/wiki/Xi_Jinping" title="Xi Jinping">Xi Jinping</a> in Beijing.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-483"><a href="#cite_note-483">[483]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-484"><a href="#cite_note-484">[484]</a></sup> He then went to India, where he spoke at the Hindustan Times Leadership Summit before meeting with Indian Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Narendra_Modi" title="Narendra Modi">Narendra Modi</a> over lunch. In addition, he held a town hall for young leaders, organized by the Obama Foundation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-485"><a href="#cite_note-485">[485]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-486"><a href="#cite_note-486">[486]</a></sup> He also met with the <a href="/wiki/Dalai_Lama" title="Dalai Lama">Dalai Lama</a> while in New Delhi.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-487"><a href="#cite_note-487">[487]</a></sup> He ended his five-day trip in France where he met with French President <a href="/wiki/Emmanuel_Macron" title="Emmanuel Macron">Emmanuel Macron</a>, former President <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Francois_Hollande" title="Francois Hollande">Francois Hollande</a> and Paris Mayor <a href="/wiki/Anne_Hidalgo" title="Anne Hidalgo">Anne Hidalgo</a> and then spoke at an invitation-only event, touching on climate issues.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-488"><a href="#cite_note-488">[488]</a></sup>
</p><p>Barack and Michelle Obama signed a deal on May 22, 2018 to produce docu-series, documentaries and features for <a href="/wiki/Netflix" title="Netflix">Netflix</a> under the Obama's newly formed production company, Higher Ground Productions. On the deal, Michelle said "I have always believed in the power of storytelling to inspire us, to make us think differently about the world around us, and to help us open our minds and hearts to others".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-489"><a href="#cite_note-489">[489]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-490"><a href="#cite_note-490">[490]</a></sup>
</p><p>A package that contained a <a href="/wiki/October_2018_United_States_mail_bombing_attempts" title="October 2018 United States mail bombing attempts">pipe bomb</a> was sent to Obama's home in Washington, D.C, on October 24, 2018. The package was intercepted by the Secret Service during routine mail screenings. Similar packages were sent to several other Democratic leaders, mostly those who voiced strong objections to the policies of <a href="/wiki/Donald_Trump" title="Donald Trump">Donald Trump</a> and to <a href="/wiki/CNN" title="CNN">CNN</a>. <a href="/wiki/Debbie_Wasserman_Schultz" title="Debbie Wasserman Schultz">Debbie Wasserman Schultz</a> was addressed as the sender of the package. On October 26, 2018, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cesar_Sayoc" title="Cesar Sayoc">Cesar Sayoc</a> was arrested and faces five federal charges in Manhattan carrying a combined maximum sentence of 48 years behind bars in relation to the pipe bombs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-491"><a href="#cite_note-491">[491]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-492"><a href="#cite_note-492">[492]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2019, Barack and Michelle Obama bought a home on <a href="/wiki/Martha%27s_Vineyard" title="Martha's Vineyard">Martha's Vineyard</a> from <a href="/wiki/Wyc_Grousbeck" title="Wyc Grousbeck">Wyc Grousbeck</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-493"><a href="#cite_note-493">[493]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-494"><a href="#cite_note-494">[494]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Legacy">Legacy</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:372px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Job_Growth_by_U.S._President_-_v1.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="778" data-file-width="1388" decoding="async" height="207" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Job_Growth_by_U.S._President_-_v1.png/370px-Job_Growth_by_U.S._President_-_v1.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Job_Growth_by_U.S._President_-_v1.png/555px-Job_Growth_by_U.S._President_-_v1.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Job_Growth_by_U.S._President_-_v1.png/740px-Job_Growth_by_U.S._President_-_v1.png 2x" width="370"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Job_Growth_by_U.S._President_-_v1.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Job growth during the presidency of Obama compared to predecessors, as measured as cumulative percentage change from month after inauguration to end of his term</div></div></div>
<p>Obama's most significant legacy is generally considered to be the <a href="/wiki/Patient_Protection_and_Affordable_Care_Act" title="Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act">Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act</a> (PPACA), provisions of which went into effect from 2010 to 2020. Many attempts by Senate Republicans to repeal the PPACA, including a "skinny repeal", have thus far failed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-legacy_495-0"><a href="#cite_note-legacy-495">[495]</a></sup> Together with the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Health_Care_and_Education_Reconciliation_Act" title="Health Care and Education Reconciliation Act">Health Care and Education Reconciliation Act</a> amendment, it represents the <a href="/wiki/Health_care_in_the_United_States" title="Health care in the United States">U.S. healthcare system</a>'s most significant regulatory overhaul and expansion of coverage since the passage of <a href="/wiki/Medicare_(United_States)" title="Medicare (United States)">Medicare</a> and <a href="/wiki/Medicaid" title="Medicaid">Medicaid</a> in 1965.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Oberlander2010_496-0"><a href="#cite_note-Oberlander2010-496">[496]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Blumenthal2015_497-0"><a href="#cite_note-Blumenthal2015-497">[497]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CohenEtAl_498-0"><a href="#cite_note-CohenEtAl-498">[498]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYTsigning_499-0"><a href="#cite_note-NYTsigning-499">[499]</a></sup>
</p><p>Many commentators credit Obama with averting a threatened <a href="/wiki/Depression_(economics)" title="Depression (economics)">depression</a> and pulling the economy back from the <a href="/wiki/Great_Recession" title="Great Recession">Great Recession</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-legacy_495-1"><a href="#cite_note-legacy-495">[495]</a></sup> According to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/U.S._Bureau_of_Labor_Statistics" title="U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics">U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Obama_administration" title="Obama administration">Obama administration</a> created 11.3¬†million jobs from the month after <a href="/wiki/First_inauguration_of_Barack_Obama" title="First inauguration of Barack Obama">his first inauguration</a> to the end of his term.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-500"><a href="#cite_note-500">[500]</a></sup> In 2010, Obama signed into effect the <a href="/wiki/Dodd%E2%80%93Frank_Wall_Street_Reform_and_Consumer_Protection_Act" title="Dodd‚ÄìFrank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act">Dodd‚ÄìFrank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act</a>. Passed as a response to the <a href="/wiki/Financial_crisis_of_2007%E2%80%9308" title="Financial crisis of 2007‚Äì08">financial crisis of 2007‚Äì08</a>, it brought the most significant changes to <a href="/wiki/Financial_regulation" title="Financial regulation">financial regulation</a> in the United States since the regulatory reform that followed the <a href="/wiki/Great_Depression" title="Great Depression">Great Depression</a> under Democratic President <a href="/wiki/Franklin_D._Roosevelt" title="Franklin D. Roosevelt">Franklin D. Roosevelt</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-501"><a href="#cite_note-501">[501]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2009, Obama signed into law the <a href="/wiki/National_Defense_Authorization_Act_for_Fiscal_Year_2010" title="National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2010">National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2010</a>, which contained in it the <a href="/wiki/Matthew_Shepard_and_James_Byrd_Jr._Hate_Crimes_Prevention_Act" title="Matthew Shepard and James Byrd Jr. Hate Crimes Prevention Act">Matthew Shepard and James Byrd Jr. Hate Crimes Prevention Act</a>, the first addition to existing federal hate crime law in the United States since Democratic President <a href="/wiki/Bill_Clinton" title="Bill Clinton">Bill Clinton</a> signed into law the Church Arson Prevention Act of 1996. The Matthew Shepard and James Byrd Jr. Hate Crimes Prevention Act expanded <a href="/wiki/Hate_crime_laws_in_the_United_States" title="Hate crime laws in the United States">existing federal hate crime laws in the United States</a> to apply to crimes motivated by a victim's actual or perceived gender, sexual orientation, gender identity, or disability, and dropped the prerequisite that the victim be engaging in a federally protected activity.
</p><p>As president, Obama advanced LGBT rights.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-502"><a href="#cite_note-502">[502]</a></sup> In 2010, he signed the <a href="/wiki/Don%27t_Ask,_Don%27t_Tell_Repeal_Act_of_2010" title="Don't Ask, Don't Tell Repeal Act of 2010">Don't Ask, Don't Tell Repeal Act</a>, which brought an end to "<a href="/wiki/Don%27t_ask,_don%27t_tell" title="Don't ask, don't tell">don't ask, don't tell</a>" policy in the U.S. armed forces that banned open service from <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lesbian,_gay_and_bisexual" title="Lesbian, gay and bisexual">LGB</a> people; the law went into effect the following year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-503"><a href="#cite_note-503">[503]</a></sup> In 2016, his administration brought an end to the ban on <a href="/wiki/Transgender" title="Transgender">transgender</a> people serving openly in the U.S. armed forces.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-504"><a href="#cite_note-504">[504]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TransBan1_219-1"><a href="#cite_note-TransBan1-219">[219]</a></sup> A <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gallup_poll" title="Gallup poll">Gallup poll</a>, taken in the final days of Obama's term, showed that 68% of Americans believed the U.S. had made progress in the situation for gays and lesbians during Obama's eight years in office.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-505"><a href="#cite_note-505">[505]</a></sup>
</p><p>Obama substantially escalated the use of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Drone_strikes" title="Drone strikes">drone strikes</a> against suspected militants and terrorists associated with <a href="/wiki/Al-Qaeda" title="Al-Qaeda">al-Qaeda</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Taliban" title="Taliban">Taliban</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-506"><a href="#cite_note-506">[506]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-507"><a href="#cite_note-507">[507]</a></sup> In 2016, the last year of his presidency, the US dropped 26,171 bombs on seven different countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-508"><a href="#cite_note-508">[508]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-509"><a href="#cite_note-509">[509]</a></sup> Obama left about 8,400 US troops in <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan" title="Afghanistan">Afghanistan</a>, 5,262 in Iraq, 503 in Syria, 133 in Pakistan, 106 in Somalia, seven in Yemen, and two in Libya at the end of his presidency.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-510"><a href="#cite_note-510">[510]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-511"><a href="#cite_note-511">[511]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to <a href="/wiki/Pew_Research_Center" title="Pew Research Center">Pew Research Center</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_States_Bureau_of_Justice_Statistics" title="United States Bureau of Justice Statistics">United States Bureau of Justice Statistics</a>, from December 31, 2009, to December 31, 2015, inmates sentenced in US federal custody declined by five percent. This is the largest decline in sentenced inmates in US federal custody since Democratic President <a href="/wiki/Jimmy_Carter" title="Jimmy Carter">Jimmy Carter</a>. By contrast, the federal prison population increased significantly under presidents <a href="/wiki/Ronald_Reagan" title="Ronald Reagan">Ronald Reagan</a>, <a href="/wiki/George_H._W._Bush" title="George H. W. Bush">George H. W. Bush</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bill_Clinton" title="Bill Clinton">Bill Clinton</a>, and <a href="/wiki/George_W._Bush" title="George W. Bush">George W. Bush</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-512"><a href="#cite_note-512">[512]</a></sup>
</p><p>Obama left office in January 2017 with a 60% approval rating.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-513"><a href="#cite_note-513">[513]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-514"><a href="#cite_note-514">[514]</a></sup> A 2018 survey of historians by the <a href="/wiki/American_Political_Science_Association" title="American Political Science Association">American Political Science Association</a> ranked Obama the <a href="/wiki/Historical_rankings_of_presidents_of_the_United_States" title="Historical rankings of presidents of the United States">8th-greatest American President</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-How_Does_Trump_Stack_Up_Against_the_Best‚Äîand_Worst‚ÄîPresidents?_4-1"><a href="#cite_note-How_Does_Trump_Stack_Up_Against_the_Best‚Äîand_Worst‚ÄîPresidents?-4">[4]</a></sup> Obama gained 10 spots from the same survey in 2015 from the <a href="/wiki/Brookings_Institution" title="Brookings Institution">Brookings Institution</a> that ranked Obama the 18th-greatest American President.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-515"><a href="#cite_note-515">[515]</a></sup>
</p><p><br/>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Presidential_library">Presidential library</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Barack_Obama_Presidential_Center" title="Barack Obama Presidential Center">Barack Obama Presidential Center</a></div>
<p>The Barack Obama Presidential Center is Obama's planned <a href="/wiki/Presidential_library" title="Presidential library">presidential library</a>. It will be hosted by the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Chicago" title="University of Chicago">University of Chicago</a> and located in <a href="/wiki/Jackson_Park_(Chicago)" title="Jackson Park (Chicago)">Jackson Park</a> on the <a href="/wiki/South_Side,_Chicago" title="South Side, Chicago">South Side of Chicago</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-516"><a href="#cite_note-516">[516]</a></sup>
</p>

<li id="cite_note-maraniss-8"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-maraniss_8-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation news">Maraniss, David (August 24, 2008). <a class="external text" href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/08/23/AR2008082301620.html" rel="nofollow">"Though Obama had to leave to find himself, it is Hawaii that made his rise possible"</a>. <i>The Washington Post</i>. p.¬†A22<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">October 28,</span> 2008</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Washington+Post&amp;rft.atitle=Though+Obama+had+to+leave+to+find+himself%2C+it+is+Hawaii+that+made+his+rise+possible&amp;rft.pages=A22&amp;rft.date=2008-08-24&amp;rft.au=Maraniss%2C+David&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.washingtonpost.com%2Fwp-dyn%2Fcontent%2Farticle%2F2008%2F08%2F23%2FAR2008082301620.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABarack+Obama"></span><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-9"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-9">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation news">Nakaso, Dan (December 22, 2008). <a class="external text" href="http://the.honoluluadvertiser.com/article/2008/Dec/22/ln/hawaii812220320.html" rel="nofollow">"Twin sisters, Obama on parallel paths for years"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/The_Honolulu_Advertiser" title="The Honolulu Advertiser">The Honolulu Advertiser</a></i>. p.¬†B1<span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-Trinity-89"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Trinity_89-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation news">Garrett, Major; Obama, Barack (March 14, 2008). <a class="external text" href="http://www.realclearpolitics.com/articles/2008/03/obama_talks_to_major_garrett_o.html" rel="nofollow">"Obama talks to Major Garrett on 'Hannity &amp; Colmes<span class="cs1-kern-right">'</span>"</a>. RealClearPolitics<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">November 10,</span> 2012</span>. <q>Major Garrett, Fox News correspondent: So the first question, how long have you been a member in good standing of that church? Sen. Barack Obama (D-IL), presidential candidate: You know, I've been a member since 1991 or '92. And‚Äîbut I have known Trinity even before then when I was a community organizer on the South Side, helping steel workers find jobs¬†... Garrett: As a member in good standing, were you a regular attendee of Sunday services? Obama: You know, I won't say that I was a perfect attendee. I was regular in spurts, because there was times when, for example, our child had just been born, our first child. And so we didn't go as regularly then.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.atitle=Obama+talks+to+Major+Garrett+on+%27Hannity+%26+Colmes%27&amp;rft.date=2008-03-14&amp;rft.aulast=Garrett&amp;rft.aufirst=Major&amp;rft.au=Obama%2C+Barack&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.realclearpolitics.com%2Farticles%2F2008%2F03%2Fobama_talks_to_major_garrett_o.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABarack+Obama"></span><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/>

<li id="cite_note-Obama_2012-97"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Obama_2012_97-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Obama, Auma (2012). <i>And then life happens: a memoir</i>. <li id="cite_note-Kenyan-161"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Kenyan_161-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">

<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Andrew_Stevenson" title="Andrew Stevenson">A. Stevenson</a> (1827‚Äì1834)</li>

<li><a href="/wiki/2006_United_States_House_of_Representatives_Democratic_Caucus_leadership_election" title="2006 United States House of Representatives Democratic Caucus leadership election">2006 House Caucus leadership election</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/2018_United_States_House_of_Representatives_Democratic_Caucus_leadership_election" title="2018 United States House of Representatives Democratic Caucus leadership election">2018 House Caucus leadership election</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Weekly_Democratic_Address" title="Weekly Democratic Address">Weekly Democratic Address</a></li></ul>
</div></td></tr></tbody></table></div>

<li><span class="nowrap"><span style="color:darkgrey">1972</span></span></li>
<li><span class="nowrap">1973: <i><a href="/wiki/L%C3%AA_%C4%90%E1%BB%A9c_Th%E1%BB%8D" title="L√™ ƒê·ª©c Th·ªç">L√™ ƒê·ª©c Th·ªç</a>¬†(declined award)</i>¬†/ <a href="/wiki/Henry_Kissinger" title="Henry Kissinger">Henry Kissinger</a></span></li>

<li><span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/Personal_computer" title="Personal computer">The Computer</a> (1982)</span></li>
<li><span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/Ronald_Reagan" title="Ronald Reagan">Ronald Reagan</a> / <a href="/wiki/Yuri_Andropov" title="Yuri Andropov">Yuri Andropov</a> (1983)</span></li>

<div aria-labelledby="Patriot_Act" class="navbox" role="navigation" style="padding:3px"><table class="nowraplinks mw-collapsible autocollapse navbox-inner" style="border-spacing:0;background:transparent;color:inherit"><tbody><tr><th class="navbox-title" colspan="2" scope="col"><div class="plainlinks hlist navbar mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Patriot_Act" title="Template:Patriot Act"><abbr style=";;background:none transparent;border:none;-moz-box-shadow:none;-webkit-box-shadow:none;box-shadow:none; padding:0;" title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Patriot_Act" title="Template talk:Patriot Act"><abbr style=";;background:none transparent;border:none;-moz-box-shadow:none;-webkit-box-shadow:none;box-shadow:none; padding:0;" title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Patriot_Act&amp;action=edit"><abbr style=";;background:none transparent;border:none;-moz-box-shadow:none;-webkit-box-shadow:none;box-shadow:none; padding:0;" title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div><div id="Patriot_Act" style="font-size:114%;margin:0 4em"><a href="/wiki/Patriot_Act" title="Patriot Act">Patriot Act</a></div></th></tr><tr><td class="navbox-abovebelow" colspan="2"><div id="Titles&amp;#10;&amp;#10;I_¬∑_II_¬∑_III_¬∑_IV_¬∑_V_¬∑_VI_¬∑_VII_¬∑_VIII_¬∑_IX_¬∑_X_(History)"><b>Titles</b>

<li><a href="/wiki/United_States_Department_of_State" title="United States Department of State">Department of State</a></li>

<li><a href="/wiki/United_States_Customs_Service" title="United States Customs Service">Customs Service</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/U.S._Immigration_and_Customs_Enforcement" title="U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement">U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement</a></li></ul>
</div></td></tr><tr><th class="navbox-group" scope="row" style="width:1%">Non-government<br/>organizations</th><td class="navbox-list navbox-even hlist" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px"><div style="padding:0em 0.25em">

<div aria-labelledby="Grammy_Award_for_Best_Spoken_Word_Album" class="navbox" role="navigation" style="padding:3px"><table class="nowraplinks hlist mw-collapsible mw-collapsed navbox-inner" style="border-spacing:0;background:transparent;color:inherit"><tbody><tr><th class="navbox-title" colspan="2" scope="col" style="background:#cedff2;"><div class="plainlinks hlist navbar mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Grammy_Award_for_Best_Spoken_Word_Album" title="Template:Grammy Award for Best Spoken Word Album"><abbr style="background:#cedff2;;;background:none transparent;border:none;-moz-box-shadow:none;-webkit-box-shadow:none;box-shadow:none; padding:0;" title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Grammy_Award_for_Best_Spoken_Word_Album" title="Template talk:Grammy Award for Best Spoken Word Album"><abbr style="background:#cedff2;;;background:none transparent;border:none;-moz-box-shadow:none;-webkit-box-shadow:none;box-shadow:none; padding:0;" title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Grammy_Award_for_Best_Spoken_Word_Album&amp;action=edit"><abbr style="background:#cedff2;;;background:none transparent;border:none;-moz-box-shadow:none;-webkit-box-shadow:none;box-shadow:none; padding:0;" title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div><div id="Grammy_Award_for_Best_Spoken_Word_Album" style="font-size:114%;margin:0 4em"><a href="/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Best_Spoken_Word_Album" title="Grammy Award for Best Spoken Word Album">Grammy Award for Best Spoken Word Album</a></div></th></tr><tr><th class="navbox-group" scope="row" style="background:#cedff2;;width:1%">1959‚àí1980</th><td class="navbox-list navbox-odd" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px"><div style="padding:0em 0.25em">
